preface.para: SCENE Troy, and the Grecian camp before it.

linegroup.line: In Troy, there lies the scene. From isles of Greece
The princes orgulous, their high blood chafed,
Have to the port of Athens sent their ships,
Fraught with the ministers and instruments
Of cruel war: sixty and nine, that wore
Their crownets regal, from the Athenian bay
Put forth toward Phrygia; and their vow is made
To ransack Troy, within whose strong immures
The ravish'd Helen, Menelaus' queen,
With wanton Paris sleeps; and that's the quarrel.
To Tenedos they come;
And the deep-drawing barks do there disgorge
Their warlike fraughtage: now on Dardan plains
The fresh and yet unbruised Greeks do pitch
Their brave pavilions: Priam's six-gated city,
Dardan, and Tymbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,
And Antenorides, with massy staples
And corresponsive and fulfilling bolts,
Sperr up the sons of Troy.
Now expectation, tickling skittish spirits,
On one and other side, Trojan and Greek,
Sets all on hazard: and hither am I come
A prologue arm'd, but not in confidence
Of author's pen or actor's voice, but suited
In like conditions as our argument,
To tell you, fair beholders, that our play
Leaps o'er the vaunt and firstlings of those broils,
Beginning in the middle, starting thence away
To what may be digested in a play.
Like or find fault; do as your pleasures are:
Now good or bad, 'tis but the chance of war.

section.title: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Call here my varlet; I'll unarm again:
Why should I war without the walls of Troy,
That find such cruel battle here within?
Each Trojan that is master of his heart,
Let him to field; Troilus, alas! hath none.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Will this gear ne'er be mended?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: The Greeks are strong and skilful to their strength,
Fierce to their skill and to their fierceness valiant;
But I am weaker than a woman's tear,
Tamer than sleep, fonder than ignorance,
Less valiant than the virgin in the night
And skilless as unpractised infancy.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Well, I have told you enough of this: for my part,
I'll not meddle nor make no further. He that will
have a cake out of the wheat must needs tarry the grinding.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Have I not tarried?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ay, the grinding; but you must tarry
the bolting.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Have I not tarried?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ay, the bolting, but you must tarry the leavening.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Still have I tarried.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ay, to the leavening; but here's yet in the word
'hereafter' the kneading, the making of the cake, the
heating of the oven and the baking; nay, you must
stay the cooling too, or you may chance to burn your lips.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Patience herself, what goddess e'er she be,
Doth lesser blench at sufferance than I do.
At Priam's royal table do I sit;
And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts,--
So, traitor! 'When she comes!' When is she thence?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Well, she looked yesternight fairer than ever I saw
her look, or any woman else.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I was about to tell thee:--when my heart,
As wedged with a sigh, would rive in twain,
Lest Hector or my father should perceive me,
I have, as when the sun doth light a storm,
Buried this sigh in wrinkle of a smile:
But sorrow, that is couch'd in seeming gladness,
Is like that mirth fate turns to sudden sadness.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: An her hair were not somewhat darker than Helen's--
well, go to--there were no more comparison between
the women: but, for my part, she is my kinswoman; I
would not, as they term it, praise her: but I would
somebody had heard her talk yesterday, as I did. I
will not dispraise your sister Cassandra's wit, but--

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O Pandarus! I tell thee, Pandarus,--
When I do tell thee, there my hopes lie drown'd,
Reply not in how many fathoms deep
They lie indrench'd. I tell thee I am mad
In Cressid's love: thou answer'st 'she is fair;'
Pour'st in the open ulcer of my heart
Her eyes, her hair, her cheek, her gait, her voice,
Handlest in thy discourse, O, that her hand,
In whose comparison all whites are ink,
Writing their own reproach, to whose soft seizure
The cygnet's down is harsh and spirit of sense
Hard as the palm of ploughman: this thou tell'st me,
As true thou tell'st me, when I say I love her;
But, saying thus, instead of oil and balm,
Thou lay'st in every gash that love hath given me
The knife that made it.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I speak no more than truth.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Thou dost not speak so much.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Faith, I'll not meddle in't. Let her be as she is:
if she be fair, 'tis the better for her; an she be
not, she has the mends in her own hands.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Good Pandarus, how now, Pandarus!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I have had my labour for my travail; ill-thought on of
her and ill-thought on of you; gone between and
between, but small thanks for my labour.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: What, art thou angry, Pandarus? what, with me?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Because she's kin to me, therefore she's not so fair
as Helen: an she were not kin to me, she would be as
fair on Friday as Helen is on Sunday. But what care
I? I care not an she were a black-a-moor; 'tis all one to me.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Say I she is not fair?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I do not care whether you do or no. She's a fool to
stay behind her father; let her to the Greeks; and so
I'll tell her the next time I see her: for my part,
I'll meddle nor make no more i' the matter.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Pandarus,--

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Not I.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Sweet Pandarus,--

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Pray you, speak no more to me: I will leave all as I
found it, and there an end.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Peace, you ungracious clamours! peace, rude sounds!
Fools on both sides! Helen must needs be fair,
When with your blood you daily paint her thus.
I cannot fight upon this argument;
It is too starved a subject for my sword.
But Pandarus,--O gods, how do you plague me!
I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar;
And he's as tetchy to be woo'd to woo.
As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit.
Tell me, Apollo, for thy Daphne's love,
What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we?
Her bed is India; there she lies, a pearl:
Between our Ilium and where she resides,
Let it be call'd the wild and wandering flood,
Ourself the merchant, and this sailing Pandar
Our doubtful hope, our convoy and our bark.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: How now, Prince Troilus! wherefore not afield?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Because not there: this woman's answer sorts,
For womanish it is to be from thence.
What news, AEneas, from the field to-day?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: That Paris is returned home and hurt.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: By whom, AEneas?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Troilus, by Menelaus.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Let Paris bleed; 'tis but a scar to scorn;
Paris is gored with Menelaus' horn.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Hark, what good sport is out of town to-day!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Better at home, if 'would I might' were 'may.'
But to the sport abroad: are you bound thither?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: In all swift haste.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Come, go we then together.

section.title: SCENE II. The Same. A street.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Who were those went by?

linegroup.speaker: ALEXANDER
linegroup.line: Queen Hecuba and Helen.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: And whither go they?

linegroup.speaker: ALEXANDER
linegroup.line: Up to the eastern tower,
Whose height commands as subject all the vale,
To see the battle. Hector, whose patience
Is, as a virtue, fix'd, to-day was moved:
He chid Andromache and struck his armourer,
And, like as there were husbandry in war,
Before the sun rose he was harness'd light,
And to the field goes he; where every flower
Did, as a prophet, weep what it foresaw
In Hector's wrath.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: What was his cause of anger?

linegroup.speaker: ALEXANDER
linegroup.line: The noise goes, this: there is among the Greeks
A lord of Trojan blood, nephew to Hector;
They call him Ajax.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Good; and what of him?

linegroup.speaker: ALEXANDER
linegroup.line: They say he is a very man per se,
And stands alone.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: So do all men, unless they are drunk, sick, or have no legs.

linegroup.speaker: ALEXANDER
linegroup.line: This man, lady, hath robbed many beasts of their
particular additions; he is as valiant as the lion,
churlish as the bear, slow as the elephant: a man
into whom nature hath so crowded humours that his
valour is crushed into folly, his folly sauced with
discretion: there is no man hath a virtue that he
hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint but he
carries some stain of it: he is melancholy without
cause, and merry against the hair: he hath the
joints of every thing, but everything so out of joint
that he is a gouty Briareus, many hands and no use,
or purblind Argus, all eyes and no sight.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: But how should this man, that makes
me smile, make Hector angry?

linegroup.speaker: ALEXANDER
linegroup.line: They say he yesterday coped Hector in the battle and
struck him down, the disdain and shame whereof hath
ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Who comes here?

linegroup.speaker: ALEXANDER
linegroup.line: Madam, your uncle Pandarus.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Hector's a gallant man.

linegroup.speaker: ALEXANDER
linegroup.line: As may be in the world, lady.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: What's that? what's that?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Good morrow, uncle Pandarus.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Good morrow, cousin Cressid: what do you talk of?
Good morrow, Alexander. How do you, cousin? When
were you at Ilium?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: This morning, uncle.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: What were you talking of when I came? Was Hector
armed and gone ere ye came to Ilium? Helen was not
up, was she?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Hector was gone, but Helen was not up.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Even so: Hector was stirring early.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Was he angry?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: So he says here.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: True, he was so: I know the cause too: he'll lay
about him to-day, I can tell them that: and there's
Troilus will not come far behind him: let them take
heed of Troilus, I can tell them that too.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: What, is he angry too?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Who, Troilus? Troilus is the better man of the two.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O Jupiter! there's no comparison.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: What, not between Troilus and Hector? Do you know a
man if you see him?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Then you say as I say; for, I am sure, he is not Hector.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: 'Tis just to each of them; he is himself.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Himself! Alas, poor Troilus! I would he were.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: So he is.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Condition, I had gone barefoot to India.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: He is not Hector.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Himself! no, he's not himself: would a' were
himself! Well, the gods are above; time must friend
or end: well, Troilus, well: I would my heart were
in her body. No, Hector is not a better man than Troilus.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Excuse me.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: He is elder.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Pardon me, pardon me.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Th' other's not come to't; you shall tell me another
tale, when th' other's come to't. Hector shall not
have his wit this year.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: He shall not need it, if he have his own.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Nor his qualities.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: No matter.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Nor his beauty.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: 'Twould not become him; his own's better.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You have no judgment, niece: Helen
herself swore th' other day, that Troilus, for
a brown favour--for so 'tis, I must confess,--
not brown neither,--

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: No, but brown.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: 'Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: To say the truth, true and not true.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: She praised his complexion above Paris.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Why, Paris hath colour enough.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: So he has.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Then Troilus should have too much: if she praised
him above, his complexion is higher than his; he
having colour enough, and the other higher, is too
flaming a praise for a good complexion. I had as
lief Helen's golden tongue had commended Troilus for
a copper nose.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I swear to you. I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Then she's a merry Greek indeed.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Nay, I am sure she does. She came to him th' other
day into the compassed window,--and, you know, he
has not past three or four hairs on his chin,--

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Indeed, a tapster's arithmetic may soon bring his
particulars therein to a total.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Why, he is very young: and yet will he, within
three pound, lift as much as his brother Hector.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Is he so young a man and so old a lifter?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came
and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin--

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Juno have mercy! how came it cloven?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Why, you know 'tis dimpled: I think his smiling
becomes him better than any man in all Phrygia.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O, he smiles valiantly.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Does he not?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O yes, an 'twere a cloud in autumn.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Why, go to, then: but to prove to you that Helen
loves Troilus,--

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Troilus will stand to the proof, if you'll
prove it so.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Troilus! why, he esteems her no more than I esteem
an addle egg.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle
head, you would eat chickens i' the shell.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I cannot choose but laugh, to think how she tickled
his chin: indeed, she has a marvellous white hand, I
must needs confess,--

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Without the rack.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Alas, poor chin! many a wart is richer.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: But there was such laughing! Queen Hecuba laughed
that her eyes ran o'er.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: With mill-stones.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: And Cassandra laughed.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: But there was more temperate fire under the pot of
her eyes: did her eyes run o'er too?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: And Hector laughed.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: At what was all this laughing?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus' chin.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: An't had been a green hair, I should have laughed
too.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: They laughed not so much at the hair as at his pretty answer.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: What was his answer?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Quoth she, 'Here's but two and fifty hairs on your
chin, and one of them is white.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: This is her question.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: That's true; make no question of that. 'Two and
fifty hairs' quoth he, 'and one white: that white
hair is my father, and all the rest are his sons.'
'Jupiter!' quoth she, 'which of these hairs is Paris,
my husband? 'The forked one,' quoth he, 'pluck't
out, and give it him.' But there was such laughing!
and Helen so blushed, an Paris so chafed, and all the
rest so laughed, that it passed.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: So let it now; for it has been while going by.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Well, cousin. I told you a thing yesterday; think on't.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: So I do.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I'll be sworn 'tis true; he will weep you, an 'twere
a man born in April.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: And I'll spring up in his tears, an 'twere a nettle
against May.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Hark! they are coming from the field: shall we
stand up here, and see them as they pass toward
Ilium? good niece, do, sweet niece Cressida.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: At your pleasure.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Here, here, here's an excellent place; here we may
see most bravely: I'll tell you them all by their
names as they pass by; but mark Troilus above the rest.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Speak not so loud.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: That's AEneas: is not that a brave man? he's one of
the flowers of Troy, I can tell you: but mark
Troilus; you shall see anon.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Who's that?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: That's Antenor: he has a shrewd wit, I can tell you;
and he's a man good enough, he's one o' the soundest
judgments in whosoever, and a proper man of person.
When comes Troilus? I'll show you Troilus anon: if
he see me, you shall see him nod at me.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Will he give you the nod?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You shall see.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: If he do, the rich shall have more.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: That's Hector, that, that, look you, that; there's a
fellow! Go thy way, Hector! There's a brave man,
niece. O brave Hector! Look how he looks! there's
a countenance! is't not a brave man?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O, a brave man!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Is a' not? it does a man's heart good. Look you
what hacks are on his helmet! look you yonder, do
you see? look you there: there's no jesting;
there's laying on, take't off who will, as they say:
there be hacks!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Be those with swords?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Swords! any thing, he cares not; an the devil come
to him, it's all one: by God's lid, it does one's
heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris.
Look ye yonder, niece; is't not a gallant man too,
is't not? Why, this is brave now. Who said he came
hurt home to-day? he's not hurt: why, this will do
Helen's heart good now, ha! Would I could see
Troilus now! You shall see Troilus anon.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Who's that?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: That's Helenus. I marvel where Troilus is. That's
Helenus. I think he went not forth to-day. That's Helenus.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Can Helenus fight, uncle?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Helenus? no. Yes, he'll fight indifferent well. I
marvel where Troilus is. Hark! do you not hear the
people cry 'Troilus'? Helenus is a priest.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: What sneaking fellow comes yonder?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Where? yonder? that's Deiphobus. 'Tis Troilus!
there's a man, niece! Hem! Brave Troilus! the
prince of chivalry!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Peace, for shame, peace!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Mark him; note him. O brave Troilus! Look well upon
him, niece: look you how his sword is bloodied, and
his helm more hacked than Hector's, and how he looks,
and how he goes! O admirable youth! he ne'er saw
three and twenty. Go thy way, Troilus, go thy way!
Had I a sister were a grace, or a daughter a goddess,
he should take his choice. O admirable man! Paris?
Paris is dirt to him; and, I warrant, Helen, to
change, would give an eye to boot.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Here come more.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Asses, fools, dolts! chaff and bran, chaff and bran!
porridge after meat! I could live and die i' the
eyes of Troilus. Ne'er look, ne'er look: the eagles
are gone: crows and daws, crows and daws! I had
rather be such a man as Troilus than Agamemnon and
all Greece.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: There is among the Greeks Achilles, a better man than Troilus.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Achilles! a drayman, a porter, a very camel.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Well, well.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: 'Well, well!' why, have you any discretion? have
you any eyes? Do you know what a man is? Is not
birth, beauty, good shape, discourse, manhood,
learning, gentleness, virtue, youth, liberality,
and such like, the spice and salt that season a man?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Ay, a minced man: and then to be baked with no date
in the pie, for then the man's date's out.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You are such a woman! one knows not at what ward you
lie.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Upon my back, to defend my belly; upon my wit, to
defend my wiles; upon my secrecy, to defend mine
honesty; my mask, to defend my beauty; and you, to
defend all these: and at all these wards I lie, at a
thousand watches.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Say one of your watches.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Nay, I'll watch you for that; and that's one of the
chiefest of them too: if I cannot ward what I would
not have hit, I can watch you for telling how I took
the blow; unless it swell past hiding, and then it's
past watching.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You are such another!

linegroup.speaker: Boy
linegroup.line: Sir, my lord would instantly speak with you.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Where?

linegroup.speaker: Boy
linegroup.line: At your own house; there he unarms him.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Good boy, tell him I come.
I doubt he be hurt. Fare ye well, good niece.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Adieu, uncle.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I'll be with you, niece, by and by.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: To bring, uncle?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ay, a token from Troilus.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: By the same token, you are a bawd.
Words, vows, gifts, tears, and love's full sacrifice,
He offers in another's enterprise;
But more in Troilus thousand fold I see
Than in the glass of Pandar's praise may be;
Yet hold I off. Women are angels, wooing:
Things won are done; joy's soul lies in the doing.
That she beloved knows nought that knows not this:
Men prize the thing ungain'd more than it is:
That she was never yet that ever knew
Love got so sweet as when desire did sue.
Therefore this maxim out of love I teach:
Achievement is command; ungain'd, beseech:
Then though my heart's content firm love doth bear,
Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.

section.title: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
section.para: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Princes,
What grief hath set the jaundice on your cheeks?
The ample proposition that hope makes
In all designs begun on earth below
Fails in the promised largeness: cheques and disasters
Grow in the veins of actions highest rear'd,
As knots, by the conflux of meeting sap,
Infect the sound pine and divert his grain
Tortive and errant from his course of growth.
Nor, princes, is it matter new to us
That we come short of our suppose so far
That after seven years' siege yet Troy walls stand;
Sith every action that hath gone before,
Whereof we have record, trial did draw
Bias and thwart, not answering the aim,
And that unbodied figure of the thought
That gave't surmised shape. Why then, you princes,
Do you with cheeks abash'd behold our works,
And call them shames? which are indeed nought else
But the protractive trials of great Jove
To find persistive constancy in men:
The fineness of which metal is not found
In fortune's love; for then the bold and coward,
The wise and fool, the artist and unread,
The hard and soft seem all affined and kin:
But, in the wind and tempest of her frown,
Distinction, with a broad and powerful fan,
Puffing at all, winnows the light away;
And what hath mass or matter, by itself
Lies rich in virtue and unmingled.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: With due observance of thy godlike seat,
Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply
Thy latest words. In the reproof of chance
Lies the true proof of men: the sea being smooth,
How many shallow bauble boats dare sail
Upon her patient breast, making their way
With those of nobler bulk!
But let the ruffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Thetis, and anon behold
The strong-ribb'd bark through liquid mountains cut,
Bounding between the two moist elements,
Like Perseus' horse: where's then the saucy boat
Whose weak untimber'd sides but even now
Co-rivall'd greatness? Either to harbour fled,
Or made a toast for Neptune. Even so
Doth valour's show and valour's worth divide
In storms of fortune; for in her ray and brightness
The herd hath more annoyance by the breeze
Than by the tiger; but when the splitting wind
Makes flexible the knees of knotted oaks,
And flies fled under shade, why, then the thing of courage
As roused with rage with rage doth sympathize,
And with an accent tuned in selfsame key
Retorts to chiding fortune.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Agamemnon,
Thou great commander, nerve and bone of Greece,
Heart of our numbers, soul and only spirit.
In whom the tempers and the minds of all
Should be shut up, hear what Ulysses speaks.
Besides the applause and approbation To which,
most mighty for thy place and sway,
And thou most reverend for thy stretch'd-out life
I give to both your speeches, which were such
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece
Should hold up high in brass, and such again
As venerable Nestor, hatch'd in silver,
Should with a bond of air, strong as the axle-tree
On which heaven rides, knit all the Greekish ears
To his experienced tongue, yet let it please both,
Thou great, and wise, to hear Ulysses speak.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Speak, prince of Ithaca; and be't of less expect
That matter needless, of importless burden,
Divide thy lips, than we are confident,
When rank Thersites opes his mastic jaws,
We shall hear music, wit and oracle.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Troy, yet upon his basis, had been down,
And the great Hector's sword had lack'd a master,
But for these instances.
The specialty of rule hath been neglected:
And, look, how many Grecian tents do stand
Hollow upon this plain, so many hollow factions.
When that the general is not like the hive
To whom the foragers shall all repair,
What honey is expected? Degree being vizarded,
The unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask.
The heavens themselves, the planets and this centre
Observe degree, priority and place,
Insisture, course, proportion, season, form,
Office and custom, in all line of order;
And therefore is the glorious planet Sol
In noble eminence enthroned and sphered
Amidst the other; whose medicinable eye
Corrects the ill aspects of planets evil,
And posts, like the commandment of a king,
Sans cheque to good and bad: but when the planets
In evil mixture to disorder wander,
What plagues and what portents! what mutiny!
What raging of the sea! shaking of earth!
Commotion in the winds! frights, changes, horrors,
Divert and crack, rend and deracinate
The unity and married calm of states
Quite from their fixure! O, when degree is shaked,
Which is the ladder to all high designs,
Then enterprise is sick! How could communities,
Degrees in schools and brotherhoods in cities,
Peaceful commerce from dividable shores,
The primogenitive and due of birth,
Prerogative of age, crowns, sceptres, laurels,
But by degree, stand in authentic place?
Take but degree away, untune that string,
And, hark, what discord follows! each thing meets
In mere oppugnancy: the bounded waters
Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores
And make a sop of all this solid globe:
Strength should be lord of imbecility,
And the rude son should strike his father dead:
Force should be right; or rather, right and wrong,
Between whose endless jar justice resides,
Should lose their names, and so should justice too.
Then every thing includes itself in power,
Power into will, will into appetite;
And appetite, an universal wolf,
So doubly seconded with will and power,
Must make perforce an universal prey,
And last eat up himself. Great Agamemnon,
This chaos, when degree is suffocate,
Follows the choking.
And this neglection of degree it is
That by a pace goes backward, with a purpose
It hath to climb. The general's disdain'd
By him one step below, he by the next,
That next by him beneath; so every step,
Exampled by the first pace that is sick
Of his superior, grows to an envious fever
Of pale and bloodless emulation:
And 'tis this fever that keeps Troy on foot,
Not her own sinews. To end a tale of length,
Troy in our weakness stands, not in her strength.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Most wisely hath Ulysses here discover'd
The fever whereof all our power is sick.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: The nature of the sickness found, Ulysses,
What is the remedy?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: The great Achilles, whom opinion crowns
The sinew and the forehand of our host,
Having his ear full of his airy fame,
Grows dainty of his worth, and in his tent
Lies mocking our designs: with him Patroclus
Upon a lazy bed the livelong day
Breaks scurril jests;
And with ridiculous and awkward action,
Which, slanderer, he imitation calls,
He pageants us. Sometime, great Agamemnon,
Thy topless deputation he puts on,
And, like a strutting player, whose conceit
Lies in his hamstring, and doth think it rich
To hear the wooden dialogue and sound
'Twixt his stretch'd footing and the scaffoldage,--
Such to-be-pitied and o'er-wrested seeming
He acts thy greatness in: and when he speaks,
'Tis like a chime a-mending; with terms unsquared,
Which, from the tongue of roaring Typhon dropp'd
Would seem hyperboles. At this fusty stuff
The large Achilles, on his press'd bed lolling,
From his deep chest laughs out a loud applause;
Cries 'Excellent! 'tis Agamemnon just.
Now play me Nestor; hem, and stroke thy beard,
As he being drest to some oration.'
That's done, as near as the extremest ends
Of parallels, as like as Vulcan and his wife:
Yet god Achilles still cries 'Excellent!
'Tis Nestor right. Now play him me, Patroclus,
Arming to answer in a night alarm.'
And then, forsooth, the faint defects of age
Must be the scene of mirth; to cough and spit,
And, with a palsy-fumbling on his gorget,
Shake in and out the rivet: and at this sport
Sir Valour dies; cries 'O, enough, Patroclus;
Or give me ribs of steel! I shall split all
In pleasure of my spleen.' And in this fashion,
All our abilities, gifts, natures, shapes,
Severals and generals of grace exact,
Achievements, plots, orders, preventions,
Excitements to the field, or speech for truce,
Success or loss, what is or is not, serves
As stuff for these two to make paradoxes.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: And in the imitation of these twain--
Who, as Ulysses says, opinion crowns
With an imperial voice--many are infect.
Ajax is grown self-will'd, and bears his head
In such a rein, in full as proud a place
As broad Achilles; keeps his tent like him;
Makes factious feasts; rails on our state of war,
Bold as an oracle, and sets Thersites,
A slave whose gall coins slanders like a mint,
To match us in comparisons with dirt,
To weaken and discredit our exposure,
How rank soever rounded in with danger.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: They tax our policy, and call it cowardice,
Count wisdom as no member of the war,
Forestall prescience, and esteem no act
But that of hand: the still and mental parts,
That do contrive how many hands shall strike,
When fitness calls them on, and know by measure
Of their observant toil the enemies' weight,--
Why, this hath not a finger's dignity:
They call this bed-work, mappery, closet-war;
So that the ram that batters down the wall,
For the great swing and rudeness of his poise,
They place before his hand that made the engine,
Or those that with the fineness of their souls
By reason guide his execution.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Let this be granted, and Achilles' horse
Makes many Thetis' sons.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: What trumpet? look, Menelaus.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: From Troy.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: What would you 'fore our tent?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Is this great Agamemnon's tent, I pray you?

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Even this.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: May one, that is a herald and a prince,
Do a fair message to his kingly ears?

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: With surety stronger than Achilles' arm
'Fore all the Greekish heads, which with one voice
Call Agamemnon head and general.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Fair leave and large security. How may
A stranger to those most imperial looks
Know them from eyes of other mortals?

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: How!

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Ay;
I ask, that I might waken reverence,
And bid the cheek be ready with a blush
Modest as morning when she coldly eyes
The youthful Phoebus:
Which is that god in office, guiding men?
Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: This Trojan scorns us; or the men of Troy
Are ceremonious courtiers.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Courtiers as free, as debonair, unarm'd,
As bending angels; that's their fame in peace:
But when they would seem soldiers, they have galls,
Good arms, strong joints, true swords; and,
Jove's accord,
Nothing so full of heart. But peace, AEneas,
Peace, Trojan; lay thy finger on thy lips!
The worthiness of praise distains his worth,
If that the praised himself bring the praise forth:
But what the repining enemy commends,
That breath fame blows; that praise, sole sure,
transcends.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Sir, you of Troy, call you yourself AEneas?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Ay, Greek, that is my name.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: What's your affair I pray you?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Sir, pardon; 'tis for Agamemnon's ears.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: He hears naught privately that comes from Troy.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Nor I from Troy come not to whisper him:
I bring a trumpet to awake his ear,
To set his sense on the attentive bent,
And then to speak.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Speak frankly as the wind;
It is not Agamemnon's sleeping hour:
That thou shalt know. Trojan, he is awake,
He tells thee so himself.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Trumpet, blow loud,
Send thy brass voice through all these lazy tents;
And every Greek of mettle, let him know,
What Troy means fairly shall be spoke aloud.
We have, great Agamemnon, here in Troy
A prince call'd Hector,--Priam is his father,--
Who in this dull and long-continued truce
Is rusty grown: he bade me take a trumpet,
And to this purpose speak. Kings, princes, lords!
If there be one among the fair'st of Greece
That holds his honour higher than his ease,
That seeks his praise more than he fears his peril,
That knows his valour, and knows not his fear,
That loves his mistress more than in confession,
With truant vows to her own lips he loves,
And dare avow her beauty and her worth
In other arms than hers,--to him this challenge.
Hector, in view of Trojans and of Greeks,
Shall make it good, or do his best to do it,
He hath a lady, wiser, fairer, truer,
Than ever Greek did compass in his arms,
And will to-morrow with his trumpet call
Midway between your tents and walls of Troy,
To rouse a Grecian that is true in love:
If any come, Hector shall honour him;
If none, he'll say in Troy when he retires,
The Grecian dames are sunburnt and not worth
The splinter of a lance. Even so much.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: This shall be told our lovers, Lord AEneas;
If none of them have soul in such a kind,
We left them all at home: but we are soldiers;
And may that soldier a mere recreant prove,
That means not, hath not, or is not in love!
If then one is, or hath, or means to be,
That one meets Hector; if none else, I am he.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man
When Hector's grandsire suck'd: he is old now;
But if there be not in our Grecian host
One noble man that hath one spark of fire,
To answer for his love, tell him from me
I'll hide my silver beard in a gold beaver
And in my vantbrace put this wither'd brawn,
And meeting him will tell him that my lady
Was fairer than his grandam and as chaste
As may be in the world: his youth in flood,
I'll prove this truth with my three drops of blood.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Now heavens forbid such scarcity of youth!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Amen.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Fair Lord AEneas, let me touch your hand;
To our pavilion shall I lead you, sir.
Achilles shall have word of this intent;
So shall each lord of Greece, from tent to tent:
Yourself shall feast with us before you go
And find the welcome of a noble foe.

section.para: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Nestor!

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: What says Ulysses?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: I have a young conception in my brain;
Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: What is't?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: This 'tis:
Blunt wedges rive hard knots: the seeded pride
That hath to this maturity blown up
In rank Achilles must or now be cropp'd,
Or, shedding, breed a nursery of like evil,
To overbulk us all.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Well, and how?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: This challenge that the gallant Hector sends,
However it is spread in general name,
Relates in purpose only to Achilles.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: The purpose is perspicuous even as substance,
Whose grossness little characters sum up:
And, in the publication, make no strain,
But that Achilles, were his brain as barren
As banks of Libya,--though, Apollo knows,
'Tis dry enough,--will, with great speed of judgment,
Ay, with celerity, find Hector's purpose
Pointing on him.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: And wake him to the answer, think you?

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Yes, 'tis most meet: whom may you else oppose,
That can from Hector bring his honour off,
If not Achilles? Though't be a sportful combat,
Yet in the trial much opinion dwells;
For here the Trojans taste our dear'st repute
With their finest palate: and trust to me, Ulysses,
Our imputation shall be oddly poised
In this wild action; for the success,
Although particular, shall give a scantling
Of good or bad unto the general;
And in such indexes, although small pricks
To their subsequent volumes, there is seen
The baby figure of the giant mass
Of things to come at large. It is supposed
He that meets Hector issues from our choice
And choice, being mutual act of all our souls,
Makes merit her election, and doth boil,
As 'twere from us all, a man distill'd
Out of our virtues; who miscarrying,
What heart receives from hence the conquering part,
To steel a strong opinion to themselves?
Which entertain'd, limbs are his instruments,
In no less working than are swords and bows
Directive by the limbs.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Give pardon to my speech:
Therefore 'tis meet Achilles meet not Hector.
Let us, like merchants, show our foulest wares,
And think, perchance, they'll sell; if not,
The lustre of the better yet to show,
Shall show the better. Do not consent
That ever Hector and Achilles meet;
For both our honour and our shame in this
Are dogg'd with two strange followers.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: I see them not with my old eyes: what are they?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: What glory our Achilles shares from Hector,
Were he not proud, we all should share with him:
But he already is too insolent;
And we were better parch in Afric sun
Than in the pride and salt scorn of his eyes,
Should he 'scape Hector fair: if he were foil'd,
Why then, we did our main opinion crush
In taint of our best man. No, make a lottery;
And, by device, let blockish Ajax draw
The sort to fight with Hector: among ourselves
Give him allowance for the better man;
For that will physic the great Myrmidon
Who broils in loud applause, and make him fall
His crest that prouder than blue Iris bends.
If the dull brainless Ajax come safe off,
We'll dress him up in voices: if he fail,
Yet go we under our opinion still
That we have better men. But, hit or miss,
Our project's life this shape of sense assumes:
Ajax employ'd plucks down Achilles' plumes.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Ulysses,
Now I begin to relish thy advice;
And I will give a taste of it forthwith
To Agamemnon: go we to him straight.
Two curs shall tame each other: pride alone
Must tarre the mastiffs on, as 'twere their bone.

section.title: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Thersites!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Agamemnon, how if he had boils? full, all over,
generally?

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Thersites!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: And those boils did run? say so: did not the
general run then? were not that a botchy core?

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Dog!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Then would come some matter from him; I see none now.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Thou bitch-wolf's son, canst thou not hear?
Feel, then.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: The plague of Greece upon thee, thou mongrel
beef-witted lord!

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Speak then, thou vinewedst leaven, speak: I will
beat thee into handsomeness.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I shall sooner rail thee into wit and holiness: but,
I think, thy horse will sooner con an oration than
thou learn a prayer without book. Thou canst strike,
canst thou? a red murrain o' thy jade's tricks!

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Toadstool, learn me the proclamation.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Dost thou think I have no sense, thou strikest me thus?

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: The proclamation!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Thou art proclaimed a fool, I think.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Do not, porpentine, do not: my fingers itch.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I would thou didst itch from head to foot and I had
the scratching of thee; I would make thee the
loathsomest scab in Greece. When thou art forth in
the incursions, thou strikest as slow as another.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I say, the proclamation!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Thou grumblest and railest every hour on Achilles,
and thou art as full of envy at his greatness as
Cerberus is at Proserpine's beauty, ay, that thou
barkest at him.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Mistress Thersites!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Thou shouldest strike him.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Cobloaf!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: He would pun thee into shivers with his fist, as a
sailor breaks a biscuit.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Beating him You whoreson cur!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Do, do.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Thou stool for a witch!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Ay, do, do; thou sodden-witted lord! thou hast no
more brain than I have in mine elbows; an assinego
may tutor thee: thou scurvy-valiant ass! thou art
here but to thrash Trojans; and thou art bought and
sold among those of any wit, like a barbarian slave.
If thou use to beat me, I will begin at thy heel, and
tell what thou art by inches, thou thing of no
bowels, thou!

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: You dog!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: You scurvy lord!

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Beating him You cur!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Mars his idiot! do, rudeness; do, camel; do, do.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Why, how now, Ajax! wherefore do you thus? How now,
Thersites! what's the matter, man?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: You see him there, do you?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Ay; what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Nay, look upon him.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: So I do: what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Nay, but regard him well.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: 'Well!' why, I do so.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: But yet you look not well upon him; for whosoever you
take him to be, he is Ajax.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I know that, fool.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Ay, but that fool knows not himself.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Therefore I beat thee.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters! his
evasions have ears thus long. I have bobbed his
brain more than he has beat my bones: I will buy
nine sparrows for a penny, and his pia mater is not
worth the nineth part of a sparrow. This lord,
Achilles, Ajax, who wears his wit in his belly and
his guts in his head, I'll tell you what I say of
him.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I say, this Ajax--

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Nay, good Ajax.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Has not so much wit--

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Nay, I must hold you.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: As will stop the eye of Helen's needle, for whom he
comes to fight.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Peace, fool!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I would have peace and quietness, but the fool will
not: he there: that he: look you there.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: O thou damned cur! I shall--

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Will you set your wit to a fool's?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: No, I warrant you; for a fools will shame it.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Good words, Thersites.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What's the quarrel?

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I bade the vile owl go learn me the tenor of the
proclamation, and he rails upon me.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I serve thee not.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Well, go to, go to.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I serve here voluntarily.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Your last service was sufferance, 'twas not
voluntary: no man is beaten voluntary: Ajax was
here the voluntary, and you as under an impress.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: E'en so; a great deal of your wit, too, lies in your
sinews, or else there be liars. Hector have a great
catch, if he knock out either of your brains: a'
were as good crack a fusty nut with no kernel.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What, with me too, Thersites?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: There's Ulysses and old Nestor, whose wit was mouldy
ere your grandsires had nails on their toes, yoke you
like draught-oxen and make you plough up the wars.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What, what?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Yes, good sooth: to, Achilles! to, Ajax! to!

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I shall cut out your tongue.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: 'Tis no matter! I shall speak as much as thou
afterwards.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: No more words, Thersites; peace!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I will hold my peace when Achilles' brach bids me, shall I?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: There's for you, Patroclus.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I will see you hanged, like clotpoles, ere I come
any more to your tents: I will keep where there is
wit stirring and leave the faction of fools.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: A good riddance.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Marry, this, sir, is proclaim'd through all our host:
That Hector, by the fifth hour of the sun,
Will with a trumpet 'twixt our tents and Troy
To-morrow morning call some knight to arms
That hath a stomach; and such a one that dare
Maintain--I know not what: 'tis trash. Farewell.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Farewell. Who shall answer him?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I know not: 'tis put to lottery; otherwise
He knew his man.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: O, meaning you. I will go learn more of it.

section.title: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
section.para: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS

linegroup.speaker: PRIAM
linegroup.line: After so many hours, lives, speeches spent,
Thus once again says Nestor from the Greeks:
'Deliver Helen, and all damage else--
As honour, loss of time, travail, expense,
Wounds, friends, and what else dear that is consumed
In hot digestion of this cormorant war--
Shall be struck off.' Hector, what say you to't?

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Though no man lesser fears the Greeks than I
As far as toucheth my particular,
Yet, dread Priam,
There is no lady of more softer bowels,
More spongy to suck in the sense of fear,
More ready to cry out 'Who knows what follows?'
Than Hector is: the wound of peace is surety,
Surety secure; but modest doubt is call'd
The beacon of the wise, the tent that searches
To the bottom of the worst. Let Helen go:
Since the first sword was drawn about this question,
Every tithe soul, 'mongst many thousand dismes,
Hath been as dear as Helen; I mean, of ours:
If we have lost so many tenths of ours,
To guard a thing not ours nor worth to us,
Had it our name, the value of one ten,
What merit's in that reason which denies
The yielding of her up?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Fie, fie, my brother!
Weigh you the worth and honour of a king
So great as our dread father in a scale
Of common ounces? will you with counters sum
The past proportion of his infinite?
And buckle in a waist most fathomless
With spans and inches so diminutive
As fears and reasons? fie, for godly shame!

linegroup.speaker: HELENUS
linegroup.line: No marvel, though you bite so sharp at reasons,
You are so empty of them. Should not our father
Bear the great sway of his affairs with reasons,
Because your speech hath none that tells him so?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: You are for dreams and slumbers, brother priest;
You fur your gloves with reason. Here are
your reasons:
You know an enemy intends you harm;
You know a sword employ'd is perilous,
And reason flies the object of all harm:
Who marvels then, when Helenus beholds
A Grecian and his sword, if he do set
The very wings of reason to his heels
And fly like chidden Mercury from Jove,
Or like a star disorb'd? Nay, if we talk of reason,
Let's shut our gates and sleep: manhood and honour
Should have hare-hearts, would they but fat
their thoughts
With this cramm'd reason: reason and respect
Make livers pale and lustihood deject.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Brother, she is not worth what she doth cost
The holding.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: What is aught, but as 'tis valued?

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: But value dwells not in particular will;
It holds his estimate and dignity
As well wherein 'tis precious of itself
As in the prizer: 'tis mad idolatry
To make the service greater than the god
And the will dotes that is attributive
To what infectiously itself affects,
Without some image of the affected merit.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I take to-day a wife, and my election
Is led on in the conduct of my will;
My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears,
Two traded pilots 'twixt the dangerous shores
Of will and judgment: how may I avoid,
Although my will distaste what it elected,
The wife I chose? there can be no evasion
To blench from this and to stand firm by honour:
We turn not back the silks upon the merchant,
When we have soil'd them, nor the remainder viands
We do not throw in unrespective sieve,
Because we now are full. It was thought meet
Paris should do some vengeance on the Greeks:
Your breath of full consent bellied his sails;
The seas and winds, old wranglers, took a truce
And did him service: he touch'd the ports desired,
And for an old aunt whom the Greeks held captive,
He brought a Grecian queen, whose youth and freshness
Wrinkles Apollo's, and makes stale the morning.
Why keep we her? the Grecians keep our aunt:
Is she worth keeping? why, she is a pearl,
Whose price hath launch'd above a thousand ships,
And turn'd crown'd kings to merchants.
If you'll avouch 'twas wisdom Paris went--
As you must needs, for you all cried 'Go, go,'--
If you'll confess he brought home noble prize--
As you must needs, for you all clapp'd your hands
And cried 'Inestimable!'--why do you now
The issue of your proper wisdoms rate,
And do a deed that fortune never did,
Beggar the estimation which you prized
Richer than sea and land? O, theft most base,
That we have stol'n what we do fear to keep!
But, thieves, unworthy of a thing so stol'n,
That in their country did them that disgrace,
We fear to warrant in our native place!

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: Within Cry, Trojans, cry!

linegroup.speaker: PRIAM
linegroup.line: What noise? what shriek is this?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: 'Tis our mad sister, I do know her voice.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: Within Cry, Trojans!

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: It is Cassandra.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: Cry, Trojans, cry! lend me ten thousand eyes,
And I will fill them with prophetic tears.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Peace, sister, peace!

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: Virgins and boys, mid-age and wrinkled eld,
Soft infancy, that nothing canst but cry,
Add to my clamours! let us pay betimes
A moiety of that mass of moan to come.
Cry, Trojans, cry! practise your eyes with tears!
Troy must not be, nor goodly Ilion stand;
Our firebrand brother, Paris, burns us all.
Cry, Trojans, cry! a Helen and a woe:
Cry, cry! Troy burns, or else let Helen go.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Now, youthful Troilus, do not these high strains
Of divination in our sister work
Some touches of remorse? or is your blood
So madly hot that no discourse of reason,
Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause,
Can qualify the same?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Why, brother Hector,
We may not think the justness of each act
Such and no other than event doth form it,
Nor once deject the courage of our minds,
Because Cassandra's mad: her brain-sick raptures
Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel
Which hath our several honours all engaged
To make it gracious. For my private part,
I am no more touch'd than all Priam's sons:
And Jove forbid there should be done amongst us
Such things as might offend the weakest spleen
To fight for and maintain!

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Else might the world convince of levity
As well my undertakings as your counsels:
But I attest the gods, your full consent
Gave wings to my propension and cut off
All fears attending on so dire a project.
For what, alas, can these my single arms?
What Propugnation is in one man's valour,
To stand the push and enmity of those
This quarrel would excite? Yet, I protest,
Were I alone to pass the difficulties
And had as ample power as I have will,
Paris should ne'er retract what he hath done,
Nor faint in the pursuit.

linegroup.speaker: PRIAM
linegroup.line: Paris, you speak
Like one besotted on your sweet delights:
You have the honey still, but these the gall;
So to be valiant is no praise at all.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Sir, I propose not merely to myself
The pleasures such a beauty brings with it;
But I would have the soil of her fair rape
Wiped off, in honourable keeping her.
What treason were it to the ransack'd queen,
Disgrace to your great worths and shame to me,
Now to deliver her possession up
On terms of base compulsion! Can it be
That so degenerate a strain as this
Should once set footing in your generous bosoms?
There's not the meanest spirit on our party
Without a heart to dare or sword to draw
When Helen is defended, nor none so noble
Whose life were ill bestow'd or death unfamed
Where Helen is the subject; then, I say,
Well may we fight for her whom, we know well,
The world's large spaces cannot parallel.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Paris and Troilus, you have both said well,
And on the cause and question now in hand
Have glozed, but superficially: not much
Unlike young men, whom Aristotle thought
Unfit to hear moral philosophy:
The reasons you allege do more conduce
To the hot passion of distemper'd blood
Than to make up a free determination
'Twixt right and wrong, for pleasure and revenge
Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice
Of any true decision. Nature craves
All dues be render'd to their owners: now,
What nearer debt in all humanity
Than wife is to the husband? If this law
Of nature be corrupted through affection,
And that great minds, of partial indulgence
To their benumbed wills, resist the same,
There is a law in each well-order'd nation
To curb those raging appetites that are
Most disobedient and refractory.
If Helen then be wife to Sparta's king,
As it is known she is, these moral laws
Of nature and of nations speak aloud
To have her back return'd: thus to persist
In doing wrong extenuates not wrong,
But makes it much more heavy. Hector's opinion
Is this in way of truth; yet ne'ertheless,
My spritely brethren, I propend to you
In resolution to keep Helen still,
For 'tis a cause that hath no mean dependance
Upon our joint and several dignities.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Why, there you touch'd the life of our design:
Were it not glory that we more affected
Than the performance of our heaving spleens,
I would not wish a drop of Trojan blood
Spent more in her defence. But, worthy Hector,
She is a theme of honour and renown,
A spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds,
Whose present courage may beat down our foes,
And fame in time to come canonize us;
For, I presume, brave Hector would not lose
So rich advantage of a promised glory
As smiles upon the forehead of this action
For the wide world's revenue.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I am yours,
You valiant offspring of great Priamus.
I have a roisting challenge sent amongst
The dun and factious nobles of the Greeks
Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits:
I was advertised their great general slept,
Whilst emulation in the army crept:
This, I presume, will wake him.

section.title: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: How now, Thersites! what lost in the labyrinth of
thy fury! Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He
beats me, and I rail at him: O, worthy satisfaction!
would it were otherwise; that I could beat him,
whilst he railed at me. 'Sfoot, I'll learn to
conjure and raise devils, but I'll see some issue of
my spiteful execrations. Then there's Achilles, a
rare enginer! If Troy be not taken till these two
undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of
themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus,
forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods and,
Mercury, lose all the serpentine craft of thy
caduceus, if ye take not that little, little less
than little wit from them that they have! which
short-armed ignorance itself knows is so abundant
scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a fly
from a spider, without drawing their massy irons and
cutting the web. After this, the vengeance on the
whole camp! or rather, the bone-ache! for that,
methinks, is the curse dependent on those that war
for a placket. I have said my prayers and devil Envy
say Amen. What ho! my Lord Achilles!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Who's there? Thersites! Good Thersites, come in and rail.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: If I could have remembered a gilt counterfeit, thou
wouldst not have slipped out of my contemplation: but
it is no matter; thyself upon thyself! The common
curse of mankind, folly and ignorance, be thine in
great revenue! heaven bless thee from a tutor, and
discipline come not near thee! Let thy blood be thy
direction till thy death! then if she that lays thee
out says thou art a fair corse, I'll be sworn and
sworn upon't she never shrouded any but lazars.
Amen. Where's Achilles?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: What, art thou devout? wast thou in prayer?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Ay: the heavens hear me!

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Who's there?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Thersites, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Where, where? Art thou come? why, my cheese, my
digestion, why hast thou not served thyself in to
my table so many meals? Come, what's Agamemnon?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Thy commander, Achilles. Then tell me, Patroclus,
what's Achilles?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Thy lord, Thersites: then tell me, I pray thee,
what's thyself?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Thy knower, Patroclus: then tell me, Patroclus,
what art thou?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Thou mayst tell that knowest.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: O, tell, tell.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I'll decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands
Achilles; Achilles is my lord; I am Patroclus'
knower, and Patroclus is a fool.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: You rascal!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Peace, fool! I have not done.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: He is a privileged man. Proceed, Thersites.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Agamemnon is a fool; Achilles is a fool; Thersites
is a fool, and, as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Derive this; come.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles;
Achilles is a fool to be commanded of Agamemnon;
Thersites is a fool to serve such a fool, and
Patroclus is a fool positive.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Why am I a fool?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Make that demand of the prover. It suffices me thou
art. Look you, who comes here?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Patroclus, I'll speak with nobody.
Come in with me, Thersites.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Here is such patchery, such juggling and such
knavery! all the argument is a cuckold and a
whore; a good quarrel to draw emulous factions
and bleed to death upon. Now, the dry serpigo on
the subject! and war and lechery confound all!

section.para: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and AJAX

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Where is Achilles?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Within his tent; but ill disposed, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Let it be known to him that we are here.
He shent our messengers; and we lay by
Our appertainments, visiting of him:
Let him be told so; lest perchance he think
We dare not move the question of our place,
Or know not what we are.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: I shall say so to him.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: We saw him at the opening of his tent:
He is not sick.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart: you may call it
melancholy, if you will favour the man; but, by my
head, 'tis pride: but why, why? let him show us the
cause. A word, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Who, Thersites?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: He.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: No, you see, he is his argument that has his
argument, Achilles.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: All the better; their fraction is more our wish than
their faction: but it was a strong composure a fool
could disunite.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily
untie. Here comes Patroclus.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: No Achilles with him.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy:
his legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Achilles bids me say, he is much sorry,
If any thing more than your sport and pleasure
Did move your greatness and this noble state
To call upon him; he hopes it is no other
But for your health and your digestion sake,
And after-dinner's breath.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Hear you, Patroclus:
We are too well acquainted with these answers:
But his evasion, wing'd thus swift with scorn,
Cannot outfly our apprehensions.
Much attribute he hath, and much the reason
Why we ascribe it to him; yet all his virtues,
Not virtuously on his own part beheld,
Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss,
Yea, like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish,
Are like to rot untasted. Go and tell him,
We come to speak with him; and you shall not sin,
If you do say we think him over-proud
And under-honest, in self-assumption greater
Than in the note of judgment; and worthier
than himself
Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on,
Disguise the holy strength of their command,
And underwrite in an observing kind
His humorous predominance; yea, watch
His pettish lunes, his ebbs, his flows, as if
The passage and whole carriage of this action
Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add,
That if he overhold his price so much,
We'll none of him; but let him, like an engine
Not portable, lie under this report:
'Bring action hither, this cannot go to war:
A stirring dwarf we do allowance give
Before a sleeping giant.' Tell him so.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: I shall; and bring his answer presently.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: In second voice we'll not be satisfied;
We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: What is he more than another?

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: No more than what he thinks he is.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a
better man than I am?

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: No question.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is?

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant, as
wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether
more tractable.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I
know not what pride is.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the
fairer. He that is proud eats up himself: pride is
his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle;
and whatever praises itself but in the deed, devours
the deed in the praise.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I do hate a proud man, as I hate the engendering of toads.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Yet he loves himself: is't not strange?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Achilles will not to the field to-morrow.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: What's his excuse?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: He doth rely on none,
But carries on the stream of his dispose
Without observance or respect of any,
In will peculiar and in self-admission.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Why will he not upon our fair request
Untent his person and share the air with us?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Things small as nothing, for request's sake only,
He makes important: possess'd he is with greatness,
And speaks not to himself but with a pride
That quarrels at self-breath: imagined worth
Holds in his blood such swoln and hot discourse
That 'twixt his mental and his active parts
Kingdom'd Achilles in commotion rages
And batters down himself: what should I say?
He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it
Cry 'No recovery.'

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Let Ajax go to him.
Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent:
'Tis said he holds you well, and will be led
At your request a little from himself.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: O Agamemnon, let it not be so!
We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes
When they go from Achilles: shall the proud lord
That bastes his arrogance with his own seam
And never suffers matter of the world
Enter his thoughts, save such as do revolve
And ruminate himself, shall he be worshipp'd
Of that we hold an idol more than he?
No, this thrice worthy and right valiant lord
Must not so stale his palm, nobly acquired;
Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit,
As amply titled as Achilles is,
By going to Achilles:
That were to enlard his fat already pride
And add more coals to Cancer when he burns
With entertaining great Hyperion.
This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid,
And say in thunder 'Achilles go to him.'

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Aside to DIOMEDES O, this is well; he rubs the
vein of him.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Aside to NESTOR And how his silence drinks up
this applause!

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: If I go to him, with my armed fist I'll pash him o'er the face.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: O, no, you shall not go.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: An a' be proud with me, I'll pheeze his pride:
Let me go to him.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: A paltry, insolent fellow!

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: How he describes himself!

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Can he not be sociable?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: The raven chides blackness.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I'll let his humours blood.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: He will be the physician that should be the patient.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: An all men were o' my mind,--

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Wit would be out of fashion.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: A' should not bear it so, a' should eat swords first:
shall pride carry it?

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: An 'twould, you'ld carry half.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: A' would have ten shares.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I will knead him; I'll make him supple.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: He's not yet through warm: force him with praises:
pour in, pour in; his ambition is dry.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: To AGAMEMNON My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Our noble general, do not do so.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Why, 'tis this naming of him does him harm.
Here is a man--but 'tis before his face;
I will be silent.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Wherefore should you so?
He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: A whoreson dog, that shall pelter thus with us!
Would he were a Trojan!

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: What a vice were it in Ajax now,--

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: If he were proud,--

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Or covetous of praise,--

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Ay, or surly borne,--

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Or strange, or self-affected!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure;
Praise him that got thee, she that gave thee suck:
Famed be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature
Thrice famed, beyond all erudition:
But he that disciplined thy arms to fight,
Let Mars divide eternity in twain,
And give him half: and, for thy vigour,
Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield
To sinewy Ajax. I will not praise thy wisdom,
Which, like a bourn, a pale, a shore, confines
Thy spacious and dilated parts: here's Nestor;
Instructed by the antiquary times,
He must, he is, he cannot but be wise:
Put pardon, father Nestor, were your days
As green as Ajax' and your brain so temper'd,
You should not have the eminence of him,
But be as Ajax.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Shall I call you father?

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Ay, my good son.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Be ruled by him, Lord Ajax.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: There is no tarrying here; the hart Achilles
Keeps thicket. Please it our great general
To call together all his state of war;
Fresh kings are come to Troy: to-morrow
We must with all our main of power stand fast:
And here's a lord,--come knights from east to west,
And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep:
Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.

section.title: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Friend, you! pray you, a word: do not you follow
the young Lord Paris?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: Ay, sir, when he goes before me.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You depend upon him, I mean?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: Sir, I do depend upon the lord.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You depend upon a noble gentleman; I must needs
praise him.

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: The lord be praised!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You know me, do you not?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: Faith, sir, superficially.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Friend, know me better; I am the Lord Pandarus.

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: I hope I shall know your honour better.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I do desire it.

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: You are in the state of grace.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Grace! not so, friend: honour and lordship are my titles.
What music is this?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: I do but partly know, sir: it is music in parts.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Know you the musicians?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: Wholly, sir.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Who play they to?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: To the hearers, sir.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: At whose pleasure, friend

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: At mine, sir, and theirs that love music.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Command, I mean, friend.

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: Who shall I command, sir?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Friend, we understand not one another: I am too
courtly and thou art too cunning. At whose request
do these men play?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: That's to 't indeed, sir: marry, sir, at the request
of Paris my lord, who's there in person; with him,
the mortal Venus, the heart-blood of beauty, love's
invisible soul,--

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Who, my cousin Cressida?

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: No, sir, Helen: could you not find out that by her
attributes?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: It should seem, fellow, that thou hast not seen the
Lady Cressida. I come to speak with Paris from the
Prince Troilus: I will make a complimental assault
upon him, for my business seethes.

linegroup.speaker: Servant
