linegroup.line: Sodden business! there's a stewed phrase indeed!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Fair be to you, my lord, and to all this fair
company! fair desires, in all fair measure,
fairly guide them! especially to you, fair queen!
fair thoughts be your fair pillow!

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: Dear lord, you are full of fair words.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You speak your fair pleasure, sweet queen. Fair
prince, here is good broken music.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: You have broke it, cousin: and, by my life, you
shall make it whole again; you shall piece it out
with a piece of your performance. Nell, he is full
of harmony.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Truly, lady, no.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: O, sir,--

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Rude, in sooth; in good sooth, very rude.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Well said, my lord! well, you say so in fits.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I have business to my lord, dear queen. My lord,
will you vouchsafe me a word?

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: Nay, this shall not hedge us out: we'll hear you
sing, certainly.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Well, sweet queen. you are pleasant with me. But,
marry, thus, my lord: my dear lord and most esteemed
friend, your brother Troilus,--

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: My Lord Pandarus; honey-sweet lord,--

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Go to, sweet queen, to go:--commends himself most
affectionately to you,--

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: You shall not bob us out of our melody: if you do,
our melancholy upon your head!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Sweet queen, sweet queen! that's a sweet queen, i' faith.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: And to make a sweet lady sad is a sour offence.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Nay, that shall not serve your turn; that shall not,
in truth, la. Nay, I care not for such words; no,
no. And, my lord, he desires you, that if the king
call for him at supper, you will make his excuse.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: My Lord Pandarus,--

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: What says my sweet queen, my very very sweet queen?

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: What exploit's in hand? where sups he to-night?

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: Nay, but, my lord,--

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: What says my sweet queen? My cousin will fall out
with you. You must not know where he sups.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: I'll lay my life, with my disposer Cressida.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: No, no, no such matter; you are wide: come, your
disposer is sick.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Well, I'll make excuse.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ay, good my lord. Why should you say Cressida? no,
your poor disposer's sick.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: I spy.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: You spy! what do you spy? Come, give me an
instrument. Now, sweet queen.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: Why, this is kindly done.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: My niece is horribly in love with a thing you have,
sweet queen.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: She shall have it, my lord, if it be not my lord Paris.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: He! no, she'll none of him; they two are twain.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: Falling in, after falling out, may make them three.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Come, come, I'll hear no more of this; I'll sing
you a song now.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: Ay, ay, prithee now. By my troth, sweet lord, thou
hast a fine forehead.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ay, you may, you may.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: Let thy song be love: this love will undo us all.
O Cupid, Cupid, Cupid!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Love! ay, that it shall, i' faith.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Ay, good now, love, love, nothing but love.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: In good troth, it begins so.
Love, love, nothing but love, still more!
For, O, love's bow
Shoots buck and doe:
The shaft confounds,
Not that it wounds,
But tickles still the sore.
These lovers cry Oh! oh! they die!
Yet that which seems the wound to kill,
Doth turn oh! oh! to ha! ha! he!
So dying love lives still:
Oh! oh! a while, but ha! ha! ha!
Oh! oh! groans out for ha! ha! ha!
Heigh-ho!

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: In love, i' faith, to the very tip of the nose.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: He eats nothing but doves, love, and that breeds hot
blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot
thoughts beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Is this the generation of love? hot blood, hot
thoughts, and hot deeds? Why, they are vipers:
is love a generation of vipers? Sweet lord, who's
a-field to-day?

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Antenor, and all the
gallantry of Troy: I would fain have armed to-day,
but my Nell would not have it so. How chance my
brother Troilus went not?

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: He hangs the lip at something: you know all, Lord Pandarus.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Not I, honey-sweet queen. I long to hear how they
sped to-day. You'll remember your brother's excuse?

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: To a hair.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Farewell, sweet queen.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: Commend me to your niece.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I will, sweet queen.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: They're come from field: let us to Priam's hall,
To greet the warriors. Sweet Helen, I must woo you
To help unarm our Hector: his stubborn buckles,
With these your white enchanting fingers touch'd,
Shall more obey than to the edge of steel
Or force of Greekish sinews; you shall do more
Than all the island kings,--disarm great Hector.

linegroup.speaker: HELEN
linegroup.line: 'Twill make us proud to be his servant, Paris;
Yea, what he shall receive of us in duty
Gives us more palm in beauty than we have,
Yea, overshines ourself.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Sweet, above thought I love thee.

section.title: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
section.para: Enter PANDARUS and Troilus's Boy, meeting

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: How now! where's thy master? at my cousin
Cressida's?

linegroup.speaker: Boy
linegroup.line: No, sir; he stays for you to conduct him thither.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: O, here he comes.
How now, how now!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Sirrah, walk off.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Have you seen my cousin?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: No, Pandarus: I stalk about her door,
Like a strange soul upon the Stygian banks
Staying for waftage. O, be thou my Charon,
And give me swift transportance to those fields
Where I may wallow in the lily-beds
Proposed for the deserver! O gentle Pandarus,
From Cupid's shoulder pluck his painted wings
And fly with me to Cressid!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Walk here i' the orchard, I'll bring her straight.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I am giddy; expectation whirls me round.
The imaginary relish is so sweet
That it enchants my sense: what will it be,
When that the watery palate tastes indeed
Love's thrice repured nectar? death, I fear me,
Swooning destruction, or some joy too fine,
Too subtle-potent, tuned too sharp in sweetness,
For the capacity of my ruder powers:
I fear it much; and I do fear besides,
That I shall lose distinction in my joys;
As doth a battle, when they charge on heaps
The enemy flying.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: She's making her ready, she'll come straight: you
must be witty now. She does so blush, and fetches
her wind so short, as if she were frayed with a
sprite: I'll fetch her. It is the prettiest
villain: she fetches her breath as short as a
new-ta'en sparrow.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom:
My heart beats thicker than a feverous pulse;
And all my powers do their bestowing lose,
Like vassalage at unawares encountering
The eye of majesty.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Come, come, what need you blush? shame's a baby.
Here she is now: swear the oaths now to her that
you have sworn to me. What, are you gone again?
you must be watched ere you be made tame, must you?
Come your ways, come your ways; an you draw backward,
we'll put you i' the fills. Why do you not speak to
her? Come, draw this curtain, and let's see your
picture. Alas the day, how loath you are to offend
daylight! an 'twere dark, you'ld close sooner.
So, so; rub on, and kiss the mistress. How now!
a kiss in fee-farm! build there, carpenter; the air
is sweet. Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere
I part you. The falcon as the tercel, for all the
ducks i' the river: go to, go to.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: You have bereft me of all words, lady.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Words pay no debts, give her deeds: but she'll
bereave you o' the deeds too, if she call your
activity in question. What, billing again? Here's
'In witness whereof the parties interchangeably'--
Come in, come in: I'll go get a fire.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Will you walk in, my lord?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O Cressida, how often have I wished me thus!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Wished, my lord! The gods grant,--O my lord!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: What should they grant? what makes this pretty
abruption? What too curious dreg espies my sweet
lady in the fountain of our love?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: More dregs than water, if my fears have eyes.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Fears make devils of cherubims; they never see truly.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Blind fear, that seeing reason leads, finds safer
footing than blind reason stumbling without fear: to
fear the worst oft cures the worse.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O, let my lady apprehend no fear: in all Cupid's
pageant there is presented no monster.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Nor nothing monstrous neither?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Nothing, but our undertakings; when we vow to weep
seas, live in fire, eat rocks, tame tigers; thinking
it harder for our mistress to devise imposition
enough than for us to undergo any difficulty imposed.
This is the monstruosity in love, lady, that the will
is infinite and the execution confined, that the
desire is boundless and the act a slave to limit.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: They say all lovers swear more performance than they
are able and yet reserve an ability that they never
perform, vowing more than the perfection of ten and
discharging less than the tenth part of one. They
that have the voice of lions and the act of hares,
are they not monsters?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Are there such? such are not we: praise us as we
are tasted, allow us as we prove; our head shall go
bare till merit crown it: no perfection in reversion
shall have a praise in present: we will not name
desert before his birth, and, being born, his addition
shall be humble. Few words to fair faith: Troilus
shall be such to Cressid as what envy can say worst
shall be a mock for his truth, and what truth can
speak truest not truer than Troilus.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Will you walk in, my lord?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: What, blushing still? have you not done talking yet?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Well, uncle, what folly I commit, I dedicate to you.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: I thank you for that: if my lord get a boy of you,
you'll give him me. Be true to my lord: if he
flinch, chide me for it.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: You know now your hostages; your uncle's word and my
firm faith.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Nay, I'll give my word for her too: our kindred,
though they be long ere they are wooed, they are
constant being won: they are burs, I can tell you;
they'll stick where they are thrown.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Boldness comes to me now, and brings me heart.
Prince Troilus, I have loved you night and day
For many weary months.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Hard to seem won: but I was won, my lord,
With the first glance that ever--pardon me--
If I confess much, you will play the tyrant.
I love you now; but not, till now, so much
But I might master it: in faith, I lie;
My thoughts were like unbridled children, grown
Too headstrong for their mother. See, we fools!
Why have I blabb'd? who shall be true to us,
When we are so unsecret to ourselves?
But, though I loved you well, I woo'd you not;
And yet, good faith, I wish'd myself a man,
Or that we women had men's privilege
Of speaking first. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue,
For in this rapture I shall surely speak
The thing I shall repent. See, see, your silence,
Cunning in dumbness, from my weakness draws
My very soul of counsel! stop my mouth.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: And shall, albeit sweet music issues thence.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Pretty, i' faith.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: My lord, I do beseech you, pardon me;
'Twas not my purpose, thus to beg a kiss:
I am ashamed. O heavens! what have I done?
For this time will I take my leave, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Your leave, sweet Cressid!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Leave! an you take leave till to-morrow morning,--

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Pray you, content you.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: What offends you, lady?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Sir, mine own company.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: You cannot shun Yourself.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Let me go and try:
I have a kind of self resides with you;
But an unkind self, that itself will leave,
To be another's fool. I would be gone:
Where is my wit? I know not what I speak.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Well know they what they speak that speak so wisely.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Perchance, my lord, I show more craft than love;
And fell so roundly to a large confession,
To angle for your thoughts: but you are wise,
Or else you love not, for to be wise and love
Exceeds man's might; that dwells with gods above.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O that I thought it could be in a woman--
As, if it can, I will presume in you--
To feed for aye her ramp and flames of love;
To keep her constancy in plight and youth,
Outliving beauty's outward, with a mind
That doth renew swifter than blood decays!
Or that persuasion could but thus convince me,
That my integrity and truth to you
Might be affronted with the match and weight
Of such a winnow'd purity in love;
How were I then uplifted! but, alas!
I am as true as truth's simplicity
And simpler than the infancy of truth.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: In that I'll war with you.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O virtuous fight,
When right with right wars who shall be most right!
True swains in love shall in the world to come
Approve their truths by Troilus: when their rhymes,
Full of protest, of oath and big compare,
Want similes, truth tired with iteration,
As true as steel, as plantage to the moon,
As sun to day, as turtle to her mate,
As iron to adamant, as earth to the centre,
Yet, after all comparisons of truth,
As truth's authentic author to be cited,
'As true as Troilus' shall crown up the verse,
And sanctify the numbers.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Prophet may you be!
If I be false, or swerve a hair from truth,
When time is old and hath forgot itself,
When waterdrops have worn the stones of Troy,
And blind oblivion swallow'd cities up,
And mighty states characterless are grated
To dusty nothing, yet let memory,
From false to false, among false maids in love,
Upbraid my falsehood! when they've said 'as false
As air, as water, wind, or sandy earth,
As fox to lamb, as wolf to heifer's calf,
Pard to the hind, or stepdame to her son,'
'Yea,' let them say, to stick the heart of falsehood,
'As false as Cressid.'

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Go to, a bargain made: seal it, seal it; I'll be the
witness. Here I hold your hand, here my cousin's.
If ever you prove false one to another, since I have
taken such pains to bring you together, let all
pitiful goers-between be called to the world's end
after my name; call them all Pandars; let all
constant men be Troiluses, all false women Cressids,
and all brokers-between Pandars! say, amen.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Amen.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Amen.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Amen. Whereupon I will show you a chamber with a
bed; which bed, because it shall not speak of your
pretty encounters, press it to death: away!
And Cupid grant all tongue-tied maidens here
Bed, chamber, Pandar to provide this gear!

section.title: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
section.para: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, DIOMEDES, NESTOR, AJAX, MENELAUS, and CALCHAS

linegroup.speaker: CALCHAS
linegroup.line: Now, princes, for the service I have done you,
The advantage of the time prompts me aloud
To call for recompense. Appear it to your mind
That, through the sight I bear in things to love,
I have abandon'd Troy, left my possession,
Incurr'd a traitor's name; exposed myself,
From certain and possess'd conveniences,
To doubtful fortunes; sequestering from me all
That time, acquaintance, custom and condition
Made tame and most familiar to my nature,
And here, to do you service, am become
As new into the world, strange, unacquainted:
I do beseech you, as in way of taste,
To give me now a little benefit,
Out of those many register'd in promise,
Which, you say, live to come in my behalf.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: What wouldst thou of us, Trojan? make demand.

linegroup.speaker: CALCHAS
linegroup.line: You have a Trojan prisoner, call'd Antenor,
Yesterday took: Troy holds him very dear.
Oft have you--often have you thanks therefore--
Desired my Cressid in right great exchange,
Whom Troy hath still denied: but this Antenor,
I know, is such a wrest in their affairs
That their negotiations all must slack,
Wanting his manage; and they will almost
Give us a prince of blood, a son of Priam,
In change of him: let him be sent, great princes,
And he shall buy my daughter; and her presence
Shall quite strike off all service I have done,
In most accepted pain.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Let Diomedes bear him,
And bring us Cressid hither: Calchas shall have
What he requests of us. Good Diomed,
Furnish you fairly for this interchange:
Withal bring word if Hector will to-morrow
Be answer'd in his challenge: Ajax is ready.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: This shall I undertake; and 'tis a burden
Which I am proud to bear.

section.para: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Achilles stands i' the entrance of his tent:
Please it our general to pass strangely by him,
As if he were forgot; and, princes all,
Lay negligent and loose regard upon him:
I will come last. 'Tis like he'll question me
Why such unplausive eyes are bent on him:
If so, I have derision medicinable,
To use between your strangeness and his pride,
Which his own will shall have desire to drink:
It may be good: pride hath no other glass
To show itself but pride, for supple knees
Feed arrogance and are the proud man's fees.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: We'll execute your purpose, and put on
A form of strangeness as we pass along:
So do each lord, and either greet him not,
Or else disdainfully, which shall shake him more
Than if not look'd on. I will lead the way.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What, comes the general to speak with me?
You know my mind, I'll fight no more 'gainst Troy.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: What says Achilles? would he aught with us?

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Would you, my lord, aught with the general?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: No.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Nothing, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: The better.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Good day, good day.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: How do you? how do you?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What, does the cuckold scorn me?

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: How now, Patroclus!

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Good morrow, Ajax.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Ha?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Good morrow.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Ay, and good next day too.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What mean these fellows? Know they not Achilles?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: They pass by strangely: they were used to bend
To send their smiles before them to Achilles;
To come as humbly as they used to creep
To holy altars.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What, am I poor of late?
'Tis certain, greatness, once fall'n out with fortune,
Must fall out with men too: what the declined is
He shall as soon read in the eyes of others
As feel in his own fall; for men, like butterflies,
Show not their mealy wings but to the summer,
And not a man, for being simply man,
Hath any honour, but honour for those honours
That are without him, as place, riches, favour,
Prizes of accident as oft as merit:
Which when they fall, as being slippery standers,
The love that lean'd on them as slippery too,
Do one pluck down another and together
Die in the fall. But 'tis not so with me:
Fortune and I are friends: I do enjoy
At ample point all that I did possess,
Save these men's looks; who do, methinks, find out
Something not worth in me such rich beholding
As they have often given. Here is Ulysses;
I'll interrupt his reading.
How now Ulysses!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Now, great Thetis' son!

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What are you reading?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: A strange fellow here
Writes me: 'That man, how dearly ever parted,
How much in having, or without or in,
Cannot make boast to have that which he hath,
Nor feels not what he owes, but by reflection;
As when his virtues shining upon others
Heat them and they retort that heat again
To the first giver.'

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: This is not strange, Ulysses.
The beauty that is borne here in the face
The bearer knows not, but commends itself
To others' eyes; nor doth the eye itself,
That most pure spirit of sense, behold itself,
Not going from itself; but eye to eye opposed
Salutes each other with each other's form;
For speculation turns not to itself,
Till it hath travell'd and is mirror'd there
Where it may see itself. This is not strange at all.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: I do not strain at the position,--
It is familiar,--but at the author's drift;
Who, in his circumstance, expressly proves
That no man is the lord of any thing,
Though in and of him there be much consisting,
Till he communicate his parts to others:
Nor doth he of himself know them for aught
Till he behold them form'd in the applause
Where they're extended; who, like an arch,
reverberates
The voice again, or, like a gate of steel
Fronting the sun, receives and renders back
His figure and his heat. I was much wrapt in this;
And apprehended here immediately
The unknown Ajax.
Heavens, what a man is there! a very horse,
That has he knows not what. Nature, what things there are
Most abject in regard and dear in use!
What things again most dear in the esteem
And poor in worth! Now shall we see to-morrow--
An act that very chance doth throw upon him--
Ajax renown'd. O heavens, what some men do,
While some men leave to do!
How some men creep in skittish fortune's hall,
Whiles others play the idiots in her eyes!
How one man eats into another's pride,
While pride is fasting in his wantonness!
To see these Grecian lords!--why, even already
They clap the lubber Ajax on the shoulder,
As if his foot were on brave Hector's breast
And great Troy shrieking.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I do believe it; for they pass'd by me
As misers do by beggars, neither gave to me
Good word nor look: what, are my deeds forgot?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Time hath, my lord, a wallet at his back,
Wherein he puts alms for oblivion,
A great-sized monster of ingratitudes:
Those scraps are good deeds past; which are devour'd
As fast as they are made, forgot as soon
As done: perseverance, dear my lord,
Keeps honour bright: to have done is to hang
Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail
In monumental mockery. Take the instant way;
For honour travels in a strait so narrow,
Where one but goes abreast: keep then the path;
For emulation hath a thousand sons
That one by one pursue: if you give way,
Or hedge aside from the direct forthright,
Like to an enter'd tide, they all rush by
And leave you hindmost;
Or like a gallant horse fall'n in first rank,
Lie there for pavement to the abject rear,
O'er-run and trampled on: then what they do in present,
Though less than yours in past, must o'ertop yours;
For time is like a fashionable host
That slightly shakes his parting guest by the hand,
And with his arms outstretch'd, as he would fly,
Grasps in the comer: welcome ever smiles,
And farewell goes out sighing. O, let not
virtue seek
Remuneration for the thing it was;
For beauty, wit,
High birth, vigour of bone, desert in service,
Love, friendship, charity, are subjects all
To envious and calumniating time.
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin,
That all with one consent praise new-born gawds,
Though they are made and moulded of things past,
And give to dust that is a little gilt
More laud than gilt o'er-dusted.
The present eye praises the present object.
Then marvel not, thou great and complete man,
That all the Greeks begin to worship Ajax;
Since things in motion sooner catch the eye
Than what not stirs. The cry went once on thee,
And still it might, and yet it may again,
If thou wouldst not entomb thyself alive
And case thy reputation in thy tent;
Whose glorious deeds, but in these fields of late,
Made emulous missions 'mongst the gods themselves
And drave great Mars to faction.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Of this my privacy
I have strong reasons.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: But 'gainst your privacy
The reasons are more potent and heroical:
'Tis known, Achilles, that you are in love
With one of Priam's daughters.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Ha! known!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Is that a wonder?
The providence that's in a watchful state
Knows almost every grain of Plutus' gold,
Finds bottom in the uncomprehensive deeps,
Keeps place with thought and almost, like the gods,
Does thoughts unveil in their dumb cradles.
There is a mystery--with whom relation
Durst never meddle--in the soul of state;
Which hath an operation more divine
Than breath or pen can give expressure to:
All the commerce that you have had with Troy
As perfectly is ours as yours, my lord;
And better would it fit Achilles much
To throw down Hector than Polyxena:
But it must grieve young Pyrrhus now at home,
When fame shall in our islands sound her trump,
And all the Greekish girls shall tripping sing,
'Great Hector's sister did Achilles win,
But our great Ajax bravely beat down him.'
Farewell, my lord: I as your lover speak;
The fool slides o'er the ice that you should break.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: To this effect, Achilles, have I moved you:
A woman impudent and mannish grown
Is not more loathed than an effeminate man
In time of action. I stand condemn'd for this;
They think my little stomach to the war
And your great love to me restrains you thus:
Sweet, rouse yourself; and the weak wanton Cupid
Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold,
And, like a dew-drop from the lion's mane,
Be shook to air.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Shall Ajax fight with Hector?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Ay, and perhaps receive much honour by him.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I see my reputation is at stake
My fame is shrewdly gored.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: O, then, beware;
Those wounds heal ill that men do give themselves:
Omission to do what is necessary
Seals a commission to a blank of danger;
And danger, like an ague, subtly taints
Even then when we sit idly in the sun.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Go call Thersites hither, sweet Patroclus:
I'll send the fool to Ajax and desire him
To invite the Trojan lords after the combat
To see us here unarm'd: I have a woman's longing,
An appetite that I am sick withal,
To see great Hector in his weeds of peace,
To talk with him and to behold his visage,
Even to my full of view.
A labour saved!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: A wonder!

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: What?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Ajax goes up and down the field, asking for himself.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: How so?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: He must fight singly to-morrow with Hector, and is so
prophetically proud of an heroical cudgelling that he
raves in saying nothing.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: How can that be?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Why, he stalks up and down like a peacock,--a stride
and a stand: ruminates like an hostess that hath no
arithmetic but her brain to set down her reckoning:
bites his lip with a politic regard, as who should
say 'There were wit in this head, an 'twould out;'
and so there is, but it lies as coldly in him as fire
in a flint, which will not show without knocking.
The man's undone forever; for if Hector break not his
neck i' the combat, he'll break 't himself in
vain-glory. He knows not me: I said 'Good morrow,
Ajax;' and he replies 'Thanks, Agamemnon.' What think
you of this man that takes me for the general? He's
grown a very land-fish, language-less, a monster.
A plague of opinion! a man may wear it on both
sides, like a leather jerkin.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Thou must be my ambassador to him, Thersites.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Who, I? why, he'll answer nobody; he professes not
answering: speaking is for beggars; he wears his
tongue in's arms. I will put on his presence: let
Patroclus make demands to me, you shall see the
pageant of Ajax.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: To him, Patroclus; tell him I humbly desire the
valiant Ajax to invite the most valorous Hector
to come unarmed to my tent, and to procure
safe-conduct for his person of the magnanimous
and most illustrious six-or-seven-times-honoured
captain-general of the Grecian army, Agamemnon,
et cetera. Do this.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Jove bless great Ajax!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Hum!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: I come from the worthy Achilles,--

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Ha!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector to his tent,--

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Hum!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: And to procure safe-conduct from Agamemnon.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Agamemnon!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Ay, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Ha!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: What say you to't?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: God b' wi' you, with all my heart.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Your answer, sir.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: If to-morrow be a fair day, by eleven o'clock it will
go one way or other: howsoever, he shall pay for me
ere he has me.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Your answer, sir.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Fare you well, with all my heart.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: No, but he's out o' tune thus. What music will be in
him when Hector has knocked out his brains, I know
not; but, I am sure, none, unless the fiddler Apollo
get his sinews to make catlings on.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Come, thou shalt bear a letter to him straight.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Let me bear another to his horse; for that's the more
capable creature.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: My mind is troubled, like a fountain stirr'd;
And I myself see not the bottom of it.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Would the fountain of your mind were clear again,
that I might water an ass at it! I had rather be a
tick in a sheep than such a valiant ignorance.

section.title: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
section.para: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: See, ho! who is that there?

linegroup.speaker: DEIPHOBUS
linegroup.line: It is the Lord AEneas.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Is the prince there in person?
Had I so good occasion to lie long
As you, prince Paris, nothing but heavenly business
Should rob my bed-mate of my company.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: That's my mind too. Good morrow, Lord AEneas.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: A valiant Greek, AEneas,--take his hand,--
Witness the process of your speech, wherein
You told how Diomed, a whole week by days,
Did haunt you in the field.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Health to you, valiant sir,
During all question of the gentle truce;
But when I meet you arm'd, as black defiance
As heart can think or courage execute.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: The one and other Diomed embraces.
Our bloods are now in calm; and, so long, health!
But when contention and occasion meet,
By Jove, I'll play the hunter for thy life
With all my force, pursuit and policy.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: And thou shalt hunt a lion, that will fly
With his face backward. In humane gentleness,
Welcome to Troy! now, by Anchises' life,
Welcome, indeed! By Venus' hand I swear,
No man alive can love in such a sort
The thing he means to kill more excellently.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: We sympathize: Jove, let AEneas live,
If to my sword his fate be not the glory,
A thousand complete courses of the sun!
But, in mine emulous honour, let him die,
With every joint a wound, and that to-morrow!

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: We know each other well.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: We do; and long to know each other worse.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: This is the most despiteful gentle greeting,
The noblest hateful love, that e'er I heard of.
What business, lord, so early?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: I was sent for to the king; but why, I know not.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: His purpose meets you: 'twas to bring this Greek
To Calchas' house, and there to render him,
For the enfreed Antenor, the fair Cressid:
Let's have your company, or, if you please,
Haste there before us: I constantly do think--
Or rather, call my thought a certain knowledge--
My brother Troilus lodges there to-night:
Rouse him and give him note of our approach.
With the whole quality wherefore: I fear
We shall be much unwelcome.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: That I assure you:
Troilus had rather Troy were borne to Greece
Than Cressid borne from Troy.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: There is no help;
The bitter disposition of the time
Will have it so. On, lord; we'll follow you.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Good morrow, all.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: And tell me, noble Diomed, faith, tell me true,
Even in the soul of sound good-fellowship,
Who, in your thoughts, merits fair Helen best,
Myself or Menelaus?

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Both alike:
He merits well to have her, that doth seek her,
Not making any scruple of her soilure,
With such a hell of pain and world of charge,
And you as well to keep her, that defend her,
Not palating the taste of her dishonour,
With such a costly loss of wealth and friends:
He, like a puling cuckold, would drink up
The lees and dregs of a flat tamed piece;
You, like a lecher, out of whorish loins
Are pleased to breed out your inheritors:
Both merits poised, each weighs nor less nor more;
But he as he, the heavier for a whore.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: You are too bitter to your countrywoman.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: She's bitter to her country: hear me, Paris:
For every false drop in her bawdy veins
A Grecian's life hath sunk; for every scruple
Of her contaminated carrion weight,
A Trojan hath been slain: since she could speak,
She hath not given so many good words breath
As for her Greeks and Trojans suffer'd death.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do,
Dispraise the thing that you desire to buy:
But we in silence hold this virtue well,
We'll but commend what we intend to sell.
Here lies our way.

section.title: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Dear, trouble not yourself: the morn is cold.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Then, sweet my lord, I'll call mine uncle down;
He shall unbolt the gates.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Trouble him not;
To bed, to bed: sleep kill those pretty eyes,
And give as soft attachment to thy senses
As infants' empty of all thought!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Good morrow, then.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I prithee now, to bed.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Are you a-weary of me?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O Cressida! but that the busy day,
Waked by the lark, hath roused the ribald crows,
And dreaming night will hide our joys no longer,
I would not from thee.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Night hath been too brief.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Beshrew the witch! with venomous wights she stays
As tediously as hell, but flies the grasps of love
With wings more momentary-swift than thought.
You will catch cold, and curse me.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Prithee, tarry:
You men will never tarry.
O foolish Cressid! I might have still held off,
And then you would have tarried. Hark!
there's one up.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Within What, 's all the doors open here?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: It is your uncle.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: A pestilence on him! now will he be mocking:
I shall have such a life!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: How now, how now! how go maidenheads? Here, you
maid! where's my cousin Cressid?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Go hang yourself, you naughty mocking uncle!
You bring me to do, and then you flout me too.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: To do what? to do what? let her say
what: what have I brought you to do?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Come, come, beshrew your heart! you'll ne'er be good,
Nor suffer others.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ha! ha! Alas, poor wretch! ah, poor capocchia!
hast not slept to-night? would he not, a naughty
man, let it sleep? a bugbear take him!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Did not I tell you? Would he were knock'd i' the head!
Who's that at door? good uncle, go and see.
My lord, come you again into my chamber:
You smile and mock me, as if I meant naughtily.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Ha, ha!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Come, you are deceived, I think of no such thing.
How earnestly they knock! Pray you, come in:
I would not for half Troy have you seen here.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Who's there? what's the matter? will you beat
down the door? How now! what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Good morrow, lord, good morrow.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Who's there? my Lord AEneas! By my troth,
I knew you not: what news with you so early?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Is not Prince Troilus here?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Here! what should he do here?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Come, he is here, my lord; do not deny him:
It doth import him much to speak with me.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Is he here, say you? 'tis more than I know, I'll
be sworn: for my own part, I came in late. What
should he do here?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Who!--nay, then: come, come, you'll do him wrong
ere you're ware: you'll be so true to him, to be
false to him: do not you know of him, but yet go
fetch him hither; go.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: How now! what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: My lord, I scarce have leisure to salute you,
My matter is so rash: there is at hand
Paris your brother, and Deiphobus,
The Grecian Diomed, and our Antenor
Deliver'd to us; and for him forthwith,
Ere the first sacrifice, within this hour,
We must give up to Diomedes' hand
The Lady Cressida.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Is it so concluded?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: By Priam and the general state of Troy:
They are at hand and ready to effect it.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: How my achievements mock me!
I will go meet them: and, my Lord AEneas,
We met by chance; you did not find me here.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Good, good, my lord; the secrets of nature
Have not more gift in taciturnity.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Is't possible? no sooner got but lost? The devil
take Antenor! the young prince will go mad: a
plague upon Antenor! I would they had broke 's neck!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: How now! what's the matter? who was here?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ah, ah!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Why sigh you so profoundly? where's my lord? gone!
Tell me, sweet uncle, what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Would I were as deep under the earth as I am above!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O the gods! what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Prithee, get thee in: would thou hadst ne'er been
born! I knew thou wouldst be his death. O, poor
gentleman! A plague upon Antenor!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Good uncle, I beseech you, on my knees! beseech you,
what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Thou must be gone, wench, thou must be gone; thou
art changed for Antenor: thou must to thy father,
and be gone from Troilus: 'twill be his death;
'twill be his bane; he cannot bear it.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O you immortal gods! I will not go.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Thou must.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: I will not, uncle: I have forgot my father;
I know no touch of consanguinity;
No kin no love, no blood, no soul so near me
As the sweet Troilus. O you gods divine!
Make Cressid's name the very crown of falsehood,
If ever she leave Troilus! Time, force, and death,
Do to this body what extremes you can;
But the strong base and building of my love
Is as the very centre of the earth,
Drawing all things to it. I'll go in and weep,--

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Do, do.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Tear my bright hair and scratch my praised cheeks,
Crack my clear voice with sobs and break my heart
With sounding Troilus. I will not go from Troy.

section.title: SCENE III. The same. Street before Pandarus' house.
section.para: Enter PARIS, TROILUS, AENEAS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, and DIOMEDES

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: It is great morning, and the hour prefix'd
Of her delivery to this valiant Greek
Comes fast upon. Good my brother Troilus,
Tell you the lady what she is to do,
And haste her to the purpose.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Walk into her house;
I'll bring her to the Grecian presently:
And to his hand when I deliver her,
Think it an altar, and thy brother Troilus
A priest there offering to it his own heart.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: I know what 'tis to love;
And would, as I shall pity, I could help!
Please you walk in, my lords.

section.title: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Be moderate, be moderate.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Why tell you me of moderation?
The grief is fine, full, perfect, that I taste,
And violenteth in a sense as strong
As that which causeth it: how can I moderate it?
If I could temporize with my affection,
Or brew it to a weak and colder palate,
The like allayment could I give my grief.
My love admits no qualifying dross;
No more my grief, in such a precious loss.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Here, here, here he comes.
Ah, sweet ducks!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O Troilus! Troilus!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: What a pair of spectacles is here!
Let me embrace too. 'O heart,' as the goodly saying is,
'--O heart, heavy heart,
Why sigh'st thou without breaking?
where he answers again,
'Because thou canst not ease thy smart
By friendship nor by speaking.'
There was never a truer rhyme. Let us cast away
nothing, for we may live to have need of such a
verse: we see it, we see it. How now, lambs?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Cressid, I love thee in so strain'd a purity,
That the bless'd gods, as angry with my fancy,
More bright in zeal than the devotion which
Cold lips blow to their deities, take thee from me.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Have the gods envy?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Ay, ay, ay, ay; 'tis too plain a case.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: And is it true that I must go from Troy?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: A hateful truth.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: What, and from Troilus too?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: From Troy and Troilus.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Is it possible?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: And suddenly; where injury of chance
Puts back leave-taking, justles roughly by
All time of pause, rudely beguiles our lips
Of all rejoindure, forcibly prevents
Our lock'd embrasures, strangles our dear vows
Even in the birth of our own labouring breath:
We two, that with so many thousand sighs
Did buy each other, must poorly sell ourselves
With the rude brevity and discharge of one.
Injurious time now with a robber's haste
Crams his rich thievery up, he knows not how:
As many farewells as be stars in heaven,
With distinct breath and consign'd kisses to them,
He fumbles up into a lose adieu,
And scants us with a single famish'd kiss,
Distasted with the salt of broken tears.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Within My lord, is the lady ready?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Hark! you are call'd: some say the Genius so
Cries 'come' to him that instantly must die.
Bid them have patience; she shall come anon.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Where are my tears? rain, to lay this wind, or
my heart will be blown up by the root.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: I must then to the Grecians?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: No remedy.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: A woful Cressid 'mongst the merry Greeks!
When shall we see again?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Hear me, my love: be thou but true of heart,--

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: I true! how now! what wicked deem is this?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Nay, we must use expostulation kindly,
For it is parting from us:
I speak not 'be thou true,' as fearing thee,
For I will throw my glove to Death himself,
That there's no maculation in thy heart:
But 'be thou true,' say I, to fashion in
My sequent protestation; be thou true,
And I will see thee.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O, you shall be exposed, my lord, to dangers
As infinite as imminent! but I'll be true.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: And I'll grow friend with danger. Wear this sleeve.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: And you this glove. When shall I see you?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I will corrupt the Grecian sentinels,
To give thee nightly visitation.
But yet be true.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O heavens! 'be true' again!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Hear while I speak it, love:
The Grecian youths are full of quality;
They're loving, well composed with gifts of nature,
Flowing and swelling o'er with arts and exercise:
How novelty may move, and parts with person,
Alas, a kind of godly jealousy--
Which, I beseech you, call a virtuous sin--
Makes me afeard.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O heavens! you love me not.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Die I a villain, then!
In this I do not call your faith in question
So mainly as my merit: I cannot sing,
Nor heel the high lavolt, nor sweeten talk,
Nor play at subtle games; fair virtues all,
To which the Grecians are most prompt and pregnant:
But I can tell that in each grace of these
There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil
That tempts most cunningly: but be not tempted.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Do you think I will?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: No.
But something may be done that we will not:
And sometimes we are devils to ourselves,
When we will tempt the frailty of our powers,
Presuming on their changeful potency.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Within Nay, good my lord,--

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Come, kiss; and let us part.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Within Brother Troilus!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Good brother, come you hither;
And bring AEneas and the Grecian with you.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: My lord, will you be true?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Who, I? alas, it is my vice, my fault:
Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion,
I with great truth catch mere simplicity;
Whilst some with cunning gild their copper crowns,
With truth and plainness I do wear mine bare.
Fear not my truth: the moral of my wit
Is 'plain and true;' there's all the reach of it.
linegroup.para: Enter AENEAS, PARIS, ANTENOR, DEIPHOBUS, and DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Welcome, Sir Diomed! here is the lady
Which for Antenor we deliver you:
At the port, lord, I'll give her to thy hand,
And by the way possess thee what she is.
Entreat her fair; and, by my soul, fair Greek,
If e'er thou stand at mercy of my sword,
Name Cressida and thy life shall be as safe
As Priam is in Ilion.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Fair Lady Cressid,
So please you, save the thanks this prince expects:
The lustre in your eye, heaven in your cheek,
Pleads your fair usage; and to Diomed
You shall be mistress, and command him wholly.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Grecian, thou dost not use me courteously,
To shame the zeal of my petition to thee
In praising her: I tell thee, lord of Greece,
She is as far high-soaring o'er thy praises
As thou unworthy to be call'd her servant.
I charge thee use her well, even for my charge;
For, by the dreadful Pluto, if thou dost not,
Though the great bulk Achilles be thy guard,
I'll cut thy throat.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: O, be not moved, Prince Troilus:
Let me be privileged by my place and message,
To be a speaker free; when I am hence
I'll answer to my lust: and know you, lord,
I'll nothing do on charge: to her own worth
She shall be prized; but that you say 'be't so,'
I'll speak it in my spirit and honour, 'no.'

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Come, to the port. I'll tell thee, Diomed,
This brave shall oft make thee to hide thy head.
Lady, give me your hand, and, as we walk,
To our own selves bend we our needful talk.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: Hark! Hector's trumpet.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: How have we spent this morning!
The prince must think me tardy and remiss,
That sore to ride before him to the field.

linegroup.speaker: PARIS
linegroup.line: 'Tis Troilus' fault: come, come, to field with him.

linegroup.speaker: DEIPHOBUS
linegroup.line: Let us make ready straight.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Yea, with a bridegroom's fresh alacrity,
Let us address to tend on Hector's heels:
The glory of our Troy doth this day lie
On his fair worth and single chivalry.

section.title: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
section.para: Enter AJAX, armed; AGAMEMNON, ACHILLES, PATROCLUS, MENELAUS, ULYSSES, NESTOR, and others

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair,
Anticipating time with starting courage.
Give with thy trumpet a loud note to Troy,
Thou dreadful Ajax; that the appalled air
May pierce the head of the great combatant
And hale him hither.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Thou, trumpet, there's my purse.
Now crack thy lungs, and split thy brazen pipe:
Blow, villain, till thy sphered bias cheek
Outswell the colic of puff'd Aquilon:
Come, stretch thy chest and let thy eyes spout blood;
Thou blow'st for Hector.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: No trumpet answers.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: 'Tis but early days.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Is not yond Diomed, with Calchas' daughter?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: 'Tis he, I ken the manner of his gait;
He rises on the toe: that spirit of his
In aspiration lifts him from the earth.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Is this the Lady Cressid?

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Even she.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Most dearly welcome to the Greeks, sweet lady.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Our general doth salute you with a kiss.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Yet is the kindness but particular;
'Twere better she were kiss'd in general.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: And very courtly counsel: I'll begin.
So much for Nestor.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I'll take what winter from your lips, fair lady:
Achilles bids you welcome.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: I had good argument for kissing once.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: But that's no argument for kissing now;
For this popp'd Paris in his hardiment,
And parted thus you and your argument.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: O deadly gall, and theme of all our scorns!
For which we lose our heads to gild his horns.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: The first was Menelaus' kiss; this, mine:
Patroclus kisses you.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: O, this is trim!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Paris and I kiss evermore for him.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: I'll have my kiss, sir. Lady, by your leave.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: In kissing, do you render or receive?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Both take and give.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: I'll make my match to live,
The kiss you take is better than you give;
Therefore no kiss.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: I'll give you boot, I'll give you three for one.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: You're an odd man; give even or give none.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: An odd man, lady! every man is odd.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: No, Paris is not; for you know 'tis true,
That you are odd, and he is even with you.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: You fillip me o' the head.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: No, I'll be sworn.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: It were no match, your nail against his horn.
May I, sweet lady, beg a kiss of you?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: You may.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: I do desire it.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Why, beg, then.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Why then for Venus' sake, give me a kiss,
When Helen is a maid again, and his.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: I am your debtor, claim it when 'tis due.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Never's my day, and then a kiss of you.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Lady, a word: I'll bring you to your father.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: A woman of quick sense.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Fie, fie upon her!
There's language in her eye, her cheek, her lip,
Nay, her foot speaks; her wanton spirits look out
At every joint and motive of her body.
O, these encounterers, so glib of tongue,
That give accosting welcome ere it comes,
And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts
To every ticklish reader! set them down
For sluttish spoils of opportunity
And daughters of the game.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: The Trojans' trumpet.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Yonder comes the troop.

section.para: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Hail, all you state of Greece! what shall be done
To him that victory commands? or do you purpose
A victor shall be known? will you the knights
Shall to the edge of all extremity
Pursue each other, or shall be divided
By any voice or order of the field?
Hector bade ask.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Which way would Hector have it?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: He cares not; he'll obey conditions.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: 'Tis done like Hector; but securely done,
A little proudly, and great deal misprizing
The knight opposed.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: If not Achilles, sir,
What is your name?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: If not Achilles, nothing.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Therefore Achilles: but, whate'er, know this:
In the extremity of great and little,
Valour and pride excel themselves in Hector;
The one almost as infinite as all,
The other blank as nothing. Weigh him well,
And that which looks like pride is courtesy.
This Ajax is half made of Hector's blood:
In love whereof, half Hector stays at home;
Half heart, half hand, half Hector comes to seek
This blended knight, half Trojan and half Greek.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: A maiden battle, then? O, I perceive you.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Here is Sir Diomed. Go, gentle knight,
Stand by our Ajax: as you and Lord AEneas
Consent upon the order of their fight,
So be it; either to the uttermost,
Or else a breath: the combatants being kin
Half stints their strife before their strokes begin.

section.para: AJAX and HECTOR enter the lists

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: They are opposed already.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: What Trojan is that same that looks so heavy?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: The youngest son of Priam, a true knight,
Not yet mature, yet matchless, firm of word,
Speaking in deeds and deedless in his tongue;
Not soon provoked nor being provoked soon calm'd:
His heart and hand both open and both free;
For what he has he gives, what thinks he shows;
Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty,
Nor dignifies an impure thought with breath;
Manly as Hector, but more dangerous;
For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes
To tender objects, but he in heat of action
Is more vindicative than jealous love:
They call him Troilus, and on him erect
A second hope, as fairly built as Hector.
Thus says AEneas; one that knows the youth
Even to his inches, and with private soul
Did in great Ilion thus translate him to me.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: They are in action.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Now, Ajax, hold thine own!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Hector, thou sleep'st;
Awake thee!

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: His blows are well disposed: there, Ajax!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: You must no more.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Princes, enough, so please you.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I am not warm yet; let us fight again.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: As Hector pleases.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Why, then will I no more:
Thou art, great lord, my father's sister's son,
A cousin-german to great Priam's seed;
The obligation of our blood forbids
A gory emulation 'twixt us twain:
Were thy commixtion Greek and Trojan so
That thou couldst say 'This hand is Grecian all,
And this is Trojan; the sinews of this leg
All Greek, and this all Troy; my mother's blood
Runs on the dexter cheek, and this sinister
Bounds in my father's;' by Jove multipotent,
Thou shouldst not bear from me a Greekish member
Wherein my sword had not impressure made
Of our rank feud: but the just gods gainsay
That any drop thou borrow'dst from thy mother,
My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword
Be drain'd! Let me embrace thee, Ajax:
By him that thunders, thou hast lusty arms;
Hector would have them fall upon him thus:
Cousin, all honour to thee!

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I thank thee, Hector
Thou art too gentle and too free a man:
I came to kill thee, cousin, and bear hence
A great addition earned in thy death.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Not Neoptolemus so mirable,
On whose bright crest Fame with her loud'st Oyes
Cries 'This is he,' could promise to himself
A thought of added honour torn from Hector.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: There is expectance here from both the sides,
What further you will do.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: We'll answer it;
The issue is embracement: Ajax, farewell.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: If I might in entreaties find success--
As seld I have the chance--I would desire
My famous cousin to our Grecian tents.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: 'Tis Agamemnon's wish, and great Achilles
Doth long to see unarm'd the valiant Hector.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: AEneas, call my brother Troilus to me,
And signify this loving interview
To the expecters of our Trojan part;
Desire them home. Give me thy hand, my cousin;
I will go eat with thee and see your knights.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Great Agamemnon comes to meet us here.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: The worthiest of them tell me name by name;
But for Achilles, mine own searching eyes
Shall find him by his large and portly size.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Worthy of arms! as welcome as to one
That would be rid of such an enemy;
But that's no welcome: understand more clear,
What's past and what's to come is strew'd with husks
And formless ruin of oblivion;
But in this extant moment, faith and troth,
Strain'd purely from all hollow bias-drawing,
Bids thee, with most divine integrity,
From heart of very heart, great Hector, welcome.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I thank thee, most imperious Agamemnon.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: To TROILUS My well-famed lord of Troy, no
less to you.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: Let me confirm my princely brother's greeting:
You brace of warlike brothers, welcome hither.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Who must we answer?

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: The noble Menelaus.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: O, you, my lord? by Mars his gauntlet, thanks!
Mock not, that I affect the untraded oath;
Your quondam wife swears still by Venus' glove:
She's well, but bade me not commend her to you.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: Name her not now, sir; she's a deadly theme.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: O, pardon; I offend.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: I have, thou gallant Trojan, seen thee oft
Labouring for destiny make cruel way
Through ranks of Greekish youth, and I have seen thee,
As hot as Perseus, spur thy Phrygian steed,
Despising many forfeits and subduements,
When thou hast hung thy advanced sword i' the air,
Not letting it decline on the declined,
That I have said to some my standers by
'Lo, Jupiter is yonder, dealing life!'
And I have seen thee pause and take thy breath,
When that a ring of Greeks have hemm'd thee in,
Like an Olympian wrestling: this have I seen;
But this thy countenance, still lock'd in steel,
I never saw till now. I knew thy grandsire,
And once fought with him: he was a soldier good;
But, by great Mars, the captain of us all,
Never saw like thee. Let an old man embrace thee;
And, worthy warrior, welcome to our tents.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: 'Tis the old Nestor.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Let me embrace thee, good old chronicle,
That hast so long walk'd hand in hand with time:
Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: I would my arms could match thee in contention,
As they contend with thee in courtesy.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I would they could.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Ha!
By this white beard, I'ld fight with thee to-morrow.
Well, welcome, welcome! I have seen the time.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: I wonder now how yonder city stands
When we have here her base and pillar by us.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I know your favour, Lord Ulysses, well.
Ah, sir, there's many a Greek and Trojan dead,
Since first I saw yourself and Diomed
In Ilion, on your Greekish embassy.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue:
My prophecy is but half his journey yet;
For yonder walls, that pertly front your town,
Yond towers, whose wanton tops do buss the clouds,
Must kiss their own feet.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I must not believe you:
There they stand yet, and modestly I think,
The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost
A drop of Grecian blood: the end crowns all,
And that old common arbitrator, Time,
Will one day end it.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: So to him we leave it.
Most gentle and most valiant Hector, welcome:
After the general, I beseech you next
To feast with me and see me at my tent.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I shall forestall thee, Lord Ulysses, thou!
Now, Hector, I have fed mine eyes on thee;
I have with exact view perused thee, Hector,
And quoted joint by joint.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Is this Achilles?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I am Achilles.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Stand fair, I pray thee: let me look on thee.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Behold thy fill.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Nay, I have done already.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Thou art too brief: I will the second time,
As I would buy thee, view thee limb by limb.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: O, like a book of sport thou'lt read me o'er;
But there's more in me than thou understand'st.
Why dost thou so oppress me with thine eye?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Tell me, you heavens, in which part of his body
Shall I destroy him? whether there, or there, or there?
That I may give the local wound a name
And make distinct the very breach whereout
Hector's great spirit flew: answer me, heavens!

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: It would discredit the blest gods, proud man,
To answer such a question: stand again:
Think'st thou to catch my life so pleasantly
As to prenominate in nice conjecture
Where thou wilt hit me dead?

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I tell thee, yea.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Wert thou an oracle to tell me so,
I'd not believe thee. Henceforth guard thee well;
For I'll not kill thee there, nor there, nor there;
But, by the forge that stithied Mars his helm,
I'll kill thee every where, yea, o'er and o'er.
You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag;
His insolence draws folly from my lips;
But I'll endeavour deeds to match these words,
Or may I never--

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Do not chafe thee, cousin:
And you, Achilles, let these threats alone,
Till accident or purpose bring you to't:
You may have every day enough of Hector
If you have stomach; the general state, I fear,
Can scarce entreat you to be odd with him.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I pray you, let us see you in the field:
We have had pelting wars, since you refused
The Grecians' cause.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Dost thou entreat me, Hector?
To-morrow do I meet thee, fell as death;
To-night all friends.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Thy hand upon that match.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: First, all you peers of Greece, go to my tent;
There in the full convive we: afterwards,
As Hector's leisure and your bounties shall
Concur together, severally entreat him.
Beat loud the tabourines, let the trumpets blow,
That this great soldier may his welcome know.

section.para: Exeunt all except TROILUS and ULYSSES

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: My Lord Ulysses, tell me, I beseech you,
In what place of the field doth Calchas keep?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: At Menelaus' tent, most princely Troilus:
There Diomed doth feast with him to-night;
Who neither looks upon the heaven nor earth,
But gives all gaze and bent of amorous view
On the fair Cressid.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Shall sweet lord, be bound to you so much,
After we part from Agamemnon's tent,
To bring me thither?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: You shall command me, sir.
As gentle tell me, of what honour was
This Cressida in Troy? Had she no lover there
That wails her absence?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O, sir, to such as boasting show their scars
A mock is due. Will you walk on, my lord?
She was beloved, she loved; she is, and doth:
But still sweet love is food for fortune's tooth.

section.title: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I'll heat his blood with Greekish wine to-night,
Which with my scimitar I'll cool to-morrow.
Patroclus, let us feast him to the height.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Here comes Thersites.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: How now, thou core of envy!
Thou crusty batch of nature, what's the news?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Why, thou picture of what thou seemest, and idol
of idiot worshippers, here's a letter for thee.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: From whence, fragment?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Why, thou full dish of fool, from Troy.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Who keeps the tent now?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: The surgeon's box, or the patient's wound.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Well said, adversity! and what need these tricks?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Prithee, be silent, boy; I profit not by thy talk:
thou art thought to be Achilles' male varlet.

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Male varlet, you rogue! what's that?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Why, his masculine whore. Now, the rotten diseases
of the south, the guts-griping, ruptures, catarrhs,
loads o' gravel i' the back, lethargies, cold
palsies, raw eyes, dirt-rotten livers, wheezing
lungs, bladders full of imposthume, sciaticas,
limekilns i' the palm, incurable bone-ache, and the
rivelled fee-simple of the tetter, take and take
again such preposterous discoveries!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Why thou damnable box of envy, thou, what meanest
thou to curse thus?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Do I curse thee?

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Why no, you ruinous butt, you whoreson
indistinguishable cur, no.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: No! why art thou then exasperate, thou idle
immaterial skein of sleave-silk, thou green sarcenet
flap for a sore eye, thou tassel of a prodigal's
purse, thou? Ah, how the poor world is pestered
with such waterflies, diminutives of nature!

linegroup.speaker: PATROCLUS
linegroup.line: Out, gall!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Finch-egg!

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite
From my great purpose in to-morrow's battle.
Here is a letter from Queen Hecuba,
A token from her daughter, my fair love,
Both taxing me and gaging me to keep
An oath that I have sworn. I will not break it:
Fall Greeks; fail fame; honour or go or stay;
My major vow lies here, this I'll obey.
Come, come, Thersites, help to trim my tent:
This night in banqueting must all be spent.
Away, Patroclus!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: With too much blood and too little brain, these two
may run mad; but, if with too much brain and too
little blood they do, I'll be a curer of madmen.
Here's Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough and one
that loves quails; but he has not so much brain as
earwax: and the goodly transformation of Jupiter
there, his brother, the bull,--the primitive statue,
and oblique memorial of cuckolds; a thrifty
shoeing-horn in a chain, hanging at his brother's
leg,--to what form but that he is, should wit larded
with malice and malice forced with wit turn him to?
To an ass, were nothing; he is both ass and ox: to
an ox, were nothing; he is both ox and ass. To be a
dog, a mule, a cat, a fitchew, a toad, a lizard, an
owl, a puttock, or a herring without a roe, I would
not care; but to be Menelaus, I would conspire
against destiny. Ask me not, what I would be, if I
were not Thersites; for I care not to be the louse
of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus! Hey-day!
spirits and fires!

section.para: Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: We go wrong, we go wrong.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: No, yonder 'tis;
There, where we see the lights.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I trouble you.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: No, not a whit.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Here comes himself to guide you.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Welcome, brave Hector; welcome, princes all.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: So now, fair prince of Troy, I bid good night.
Ajax commands the guard to tend on you.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Thanks and good night to the Greeks' general.

linegroup.speaker: MENELAUS
linegroup.line: Good night, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Good night, sweet lord Menelaus.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Sweet draught: 'sweet' quoth 'a! sweet sink,
sweet sewer.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Good night and welcome, both at once, to those
That go or tarry.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Good night.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Old Nestor tarries; and you too, Diomed,
Keep Hector company an hour or two.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: I cannot, lord; I have important business,
The tide whereof is now. Good night, great Hector.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Give me your hand.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Aside to TROILUS Follow his torch; he goes to
Calchas' tent:
I'll keep you company.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Sweet sir, you honour me.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: And so, good night.

section.para: Exit DIOMEDES; ULYSSES and TROILUS following

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Come, come, enter my tent.

section.para: Exeunt ACHILLES, HECTOR, AJAX, and NESTOR

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: That same Diomed's a false-hearted rogue, a most
unjust knave; I will no more trust him when he leers
than I will a serpent when he hisses: he will spend
his mouth, and promise, like Brabbler the hound:
but when he performs, astronomers foretell it; it
is prodigious, there will come some change; the sun
borrows of the moon, when Diomed keeps his
word. I will rather leave to see Hector, than
not to dog him: they say he keeps a Trojan
drab, and uses the traitor Calchas' tent: I'll
after. Nothing but lechery! all incontinent varlets!

section.title: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: What, are you up here, ho? speak.

linegroup.speaker: CALCHAS
linegroup.line: Within Who calls?

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Calchas, I think. Where's your daughter?

linegroup.speaker: CALCHAS
linegroup.line: Within She comes to you.

section.para: Enter TROILUS and ULYSSES, at a distance; after them, THERSITES

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Stand where the torch may not discover us.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Cressid comes forth to him.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: How now, my charge!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Now, my sweet guardian! Hark, a word with you.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Yea, so familiar!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: She will sing any man at first sight.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: And any man may sing her, if he can take her cliff;
she's noted.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Will you remember?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Remember! yes.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Nay, but do, then;
And let your mind be coupled with your words.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: What should she remember?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: List.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Sweet honey Greek, tempt me no more to folly.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Roguery!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Nay, then,--

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: I'll tell you what,--

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Foh, foh! come, tell a pin: you are forsworn.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
