linegroup.line: In faith, I cannot: what would you have me do?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: A juggling trick,--to be secretly open.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: What did you swear you would bestow on me?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: I prithee, do not hold me to mine oath;
Bid me do any thing but that, sweet Greek.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Good night.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Hold, patience!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: How now, Trojan!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Diomed,--

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: No, no, good night: I'll be your fool no more.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Thy better must.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Hark, one word in your ear.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O plague and madness!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: You are moved, prince; let us depart, I pray you,
Lest your displeasure should enlarge itself
To wrathful terms: this place is dangerous;
The time right deadly; I beseech you, go.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Behold, I pray you!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Nay, good my lord, go off:
You flow to great distraction; come, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I pray thee, stay.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: You have not patience; come.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I pray you, stay; by hell and all hell's torments
I will not speak a word!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: And so, good night.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Nay, but you part in anger.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Doth that grieve thee?
O wither'd truth!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Why, how now, lord!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: By Jove,
I will be patient.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Guardian!--why, Greek!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Foh, foh! adieu; you palter.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: In faith, I do not: come hither once again.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: You shake, my lord, at something: will you go?
You will break out.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: She strokes his cheek!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Come, come.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Nay, stay; by Jove, I will not speak a word:
There is between my will and all offences
A guard of patience: stay a little while.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: How the devil Luxury, with his fat rump and
potato-finger, tickles these together! Fry, lechery, fry!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: But will you, then?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: In faith, I will, la; never trust me else.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Give me some token for the surety of it.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: I'll fetch you one.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: You have sworn patience.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Fear me not, sweet lord;
I will not be myself, nor have cognition
Of what I feel: I am all patience.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Now the pledge; now, now, now!

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Here, Diomed, keep this sleeve.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O beauty! where is thy faith?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: My lord,--

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I will be patient; outwardly I will.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: You look upon that sleeve; behold it well.
He loved me--O false wench!--Give't me again.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Whose was't?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: It is no matter, now I have't again.
I will not meet with you to-morrow night:
I prithee, Diomed, visit me no more.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Now she sharpens: well said, whetstone!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: I shall have it.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: What, this?

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Ay, that.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: O, all you gods! O pretty, pretty pledge!
Thy master now lies thinking in his bed
Of thee and me, and sighs, and takes my glove,
And gives memorial dainty kisses to it,
As I kiss thee. Nay, do not snatch it from me;
He that takes that doth take my heart withal.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: I had your heart before, this follows it.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: I did swear patience.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: You shall not have it, Diomed; faith, you shall not;
I'll give you something else.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: I will have this: whose was it?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: It is no matter.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Come, tell me whose it was.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: 'Twas one's that loved me better than you will.
But, now you have it, take it.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Whose was it?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: By all Diana's waiting-women yond,
And by herself, I will not tell you whose.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: To-morrow will I wear it on my helm,
And grieve his spirit that dares not challenge it.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Wert thou the devil, and worest it on thy horn,
It should be challenged.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Well, well, 'tis done, 'tis past: and yet it is not;
I will not keep my word.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Why, then, farewell;
Thou never shalt mock Diomed again.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: You shall not go: one cannot speak a word,
But it straight starts you.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: I do not like this fooling.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Nor I, by Pluto: but that that likes not you pleases me best.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: What, shall I come? the hour?

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Ay, come:--O Jove!--do come:--I shall be plagued.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Farewell till then.

linegroup.speaker: CRESSIDA
linegroup.line: Good night: I prithee, come.
Troilus, farewell! one eye yet looks on thee
But with my heart the other eye doth see.
Ah, poor our sex! this fault in us I find,
The error of our eye directs our mind:
What error leads must err; O, then conclude
Minds sway'd by eyes are full of turpitude.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: A proof of strength she could not publish more,
Unless she said ' My mind is now turn'd whore.'

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: All's done, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: It is.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Why stay we, then?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: To make a recordation to my soul
Of every syllable that here was spoke.
But if I tell how these two did co-act,
Shall I not lie in publishing a truth?
Sith yet there is a credence in my heart,
An esperance so obstinately strong,
That doth invert the attest of eyes and ears,
As if those organs had deceptious functions,
Created only to calumniate.
Was Cressid here?

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: I cannot conjure, Trojan.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: She was not, sure.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Most sure she was.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Why, my negation hath no taste of madness.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: Nor mine, my lord: Cressid was here but now.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Let it not be believed for womanhood!
Think, we had mothers; do not give advantage
To stubborn critics, apt, without a theme,
For depravation, to square the general sex
By Cressid's rule: rather think this not Cressid.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: What hath she done, prince, that can soil our mothers?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Nothing at all, unless that this were she.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Will he swagger himself out on's own eyes?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: This she? no, this is Diomed's Cressida:
If beauty have a soul, this is not she;
If souls guide vows, if vows be sanctimonies,
If sanctimony be the gods' delight,
If there be rule in unity itself,
This is not she. O madness of discourse,
That cause sets up with and against itself!
Bi-fold authority! where reason can revolt
Without perdition, and loss assume all reason
Without revolt: this is, and is not, Cressid.
Within my soul there doth conduce a fight
Of this strange nature that a thing inseparate
Divides more wider than the sky and earth,
And yet the spacious breadth of this division
Admits no orifex for a point as subtle
As Ariachne's broken woof to enter.
Instance, O instance! strong as Pluto's gates;
Cressid is mine, tied with the bonds of heaven:
Instance, O instance! strong as heaven itself;
The bonds of heaven are slipp'd, dissolved, and loosed;
And with another knot, five-finger-tied,
The fractions of her faith, orts of her love,
The fragments, scraps, the bits and greasy relics
Of her o'er-eaten faith, are bound to Diomed.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: May worthy Troilus be half attach'd
With that which here his passion doth express?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Ay, Greek; and that shall be divulged well
In characters as red as Mars his heart
Inflamed with Venus: never did young man fancy
With so eternal and so fix'd a soul.
Hark, Greek: as much as I do Cressid love,
So much by weight hate I her Diomed:
That sleeve is mine that he'll bear on his helm;
Were it a casque composed by Vulcan's skill,
My sword should bite it: not the dreadful spout
Which shipmen do the hurricano call,
Constringed in mass by the almighty sun,
Shall dizzy with more clamour Neptune's ear
In his descent than shall my prompted sword
Falling on Diomed.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: He'll tickle it for his concupy.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O Cressid! O false Cressid! false, false, false!
Let all untruths stand by thy stained name,
And they'll seem glorious.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: O, contain yourself
Your passion draws ears hither.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: I have been seeking you this hour, my lord:
Hector, by this, is arming him in Troy;
Ajax, your guard, stays to conduct you home.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Have with you, prince. My courteous lord, adieu.
Farewell, revolted fair! and, Diomed,
Stand fast, and wear a castle on thy head!

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: I'll bring you to the gates.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Accept distracted thanks.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Would I could meet that rogue Diomed! I would
croak like a raven; I would bode, I would bode.
Patroclus will give me any thing for the
intelligence of this whore: the parrot will not
do more for an almond than he for a commodious drab.
Lechery, lechery; still, wars and lechery; nothing
else holds fashion: a burning devil take them!

section.title: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.

linegroup.speaker: ANDROMACHE
linegroup.line: When was my lord so much ungently temper'd,
To stop his ears against admonishment?
Unarm, unarm, and do not fight to-day.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: You train me to offend you; get you in:
By all the everlasting gods, I'll go!

linegroup.speaker: ANDROMACHE
linegroup.line: My dreams will, sure, prove ominous to the day.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: No more, I say.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: Where is my brother Hector?

linegroup.speaker: ANDROMACHE
linegroup.line: Here, sister; arm'd, and bloody in intent.
Consort with me in loud and dear petition,
Pursue we him on knees; for I have dream'd
Of bloody turbulence, and this whole night
Hath nothing been but shapes and forms of slaughter.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: O, 'tis true.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Ho! bid my trumpet sound!

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Be gone, I say: the gods have heard me swear.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows:
They are polluted offerings, more abhorr'd
Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

linegroup.speaker: ANDROMACHE
linegroup.line: O, be persuaded! do not count it holy
To hurt by being just: it is as lawful,
For we would give much, to use violent thefts,
And rob in the behalf of charity.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: It is the purpose that makes strong the vow;
But vows to every purpose must not hold:
Unarm, sweet Hector.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Hold you still, I say;
Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate:
Lie every man holds dear; but the brave man
Holds honour far more precious-dear than life.
How now, young man! mean'st thou to fight to-day?

linegroup.speaker: ANDROMACHE
linegroup.line: Cassandra, call my father to persuade.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: No, faith, young Troilus; doff thy harness, youth;
I am to-day i' the vein of chivalry:
Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong,
And tempt not yet the brushes of the war.
Unarm thee, go, and doubt thou not, brave boy,
I'll stand to-day for thee and me and Troy.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you,
Which better fits a lion than a man.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: What vice is that, good Troilus? chide me for it.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: When many times the captive Grecian falls,
Even in the fan and wind of your fair sword,
You bid them rise, and live.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: O,'tis fair play.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Fool's play, by heaven, Hector.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: How now! how now!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: For the love of all the gods,
Let's leave the hermit pity with our mothers,
And when we have our armours buckled on,
The venom'd vengeance ride upon our swords,
Spur them to ruthful work, rein them from ruth.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Fie, savage, fie!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Hector, then 'tis wars.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Troilus, I would not have you fight to-day.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Who should withhold me?
Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars
Beckoning with fiery truncheon my retire;
Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees,
Their eyes o'ergalled with recourse of tears;
Not you, my brother, with your true sword drawn,
Opposed to hinder me, should stop my way,
But by my ruin.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: Lay hold upon him, Priam, hold him fast:
He is thy crutch; now if thou lose thy stay,
Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee,
Fall all together.

linegroup.speaker: PRIAM
linegroup.line: Come, Hector, come, go back:
Thy wife hath dream'd; thy mother hath had visions;
Cassandra doth foresee; and I myself
Am like a prophet suddenly enrapt
To tell thee that this day is ominous:
Therefore, come back.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: AEneas is a-field;
And I do stand engaged to many Greeks,
Even in the faith of valour, to appear
This morning to them.

linegroup.speaker: PRIAM
linegroup.line: Ay, but thou shalt not go.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I must not break my faith.
You know me dutiful; therefore, dear sir,
Let me not shame respect; but give me leave
To take that course by your consent and voice,
Which you do here forbid me, royal Priam.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: O Priam, yield not to him!

linegroup.speaker: ANDROMACHE
linegroup.line: Do not, dear father.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Andromache, I am offended with you:
Upon the love you bear me, get you in.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl
Makes all these bodements.

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: O, farewell, dear Hector!
Look, how thou diest! look, how thy eye turns pale!
Look, how thy wounds do bleed at many vents!
Hark, how Troy roars! how Hecuba cries out!
How poor Andromache shrills her dolours forth!
Behold, distraction, frenzy and amazement,
Like witless antics, one another meet,
And all cry, Hector! Hector's dead! O Hector!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Away! away!

linegroup.speaker: CASSANDRA
linegroup.line: Farewell: yet, soft! Hector! take my leave:
Thou dost thyself and all our Troy deceive.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: You are amazed, my liege, at her exclaim:
Go in and cheer the town: we'll forth and fight,
Do deeds worth praise and tell you them at night.

linegroup.speaker: PRIAM
linegroup.line: Farewell: the gods with safety stand about thee!

section.para: Exeunt severally PRIAM and HECTOR. Alarums

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe,
I come to lose my arm, or win my sleeve.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Do you hear, my lord? do you hear?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: What now?

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: Here's a letter come from yond poor girl.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Let me read.

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: A whoreson tisick, a whoreson rascally tisick so
troubles me, and the foolish fortune of this girl;
and what one thing, what another, that I shall
leave you one o' these days: and I have a rheum
in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my bones
that, unless a man were cursed, I cannot tell what
to think on't. What says she there?

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart:
The effect doth operate another way.
Go, wind, to wind, there turn and change together.
My love with words and errors still she feeds;
But edifies another with her deeds.

section.title: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I'll go
look on. That dissembling abominable varlets Diomed,
has got that same scurvy doting foolish young knave's
sleeve of Troy there in his helm: I would fain see
them meet; that that same young Trojan ass, that
loves the whore there, might send that Greekish
whore-masterly villain, with the sleeve, back to the
dissembling luxurious drab, of a sleeveless errand.
O' the t'other side, the policy of those crafty
swearing rascals, that stale old mouse-eaten dry
cheese, Nestor, and that same dog-fox, Ulysses, is
not proved worthy a blackberry: they set me up, in
policy, that mongrel cur, Ajax, against that dog of
as bad a kind, Achilles: and now is the cur Ajax
prouder than the cur Achilles, and will not arm
to-day; whereupon the Grecians begin to proclaim
barbarism, and policy grows into an ill opinion.
Soft! here comes sleeve, and t'other.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Fly not; for shouldst thou take the river Styx,
I would swim after.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Thou dost miscall retire:
I do not fly, but advantageous care
Withdrew me from the odds of multitude:
Have at thee!

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: Hold thy whore, Grecian!--now for thy whore,
Trojan!--now the sleeve, now the sleeve!

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: What art thou, Greek? art thou for Hector's match?
Art thou of blood and honour?

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: No, no, I am a rascal; a scurvy railing knave:
a very filthy rogue.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I do believe thee: live.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me; but a
plague break thy neck for frightening me! What's
become of the wenching rogues? I think they have
swallowed one another: I would laugh at that
miracle: yet, in a sort, lechery eats itself.
I'll seek them.

section.title: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Go, go, my servant, take thou Troilus' horse;
Present the fair steed to my lady Cressid:
Fellow, commend my service to her beauty;
Tell her I have chastised the amorous Trojan,
And am her knight by proof.

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: I go, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Renew, renew! The fierce Polydamas
Hath beat down Menon: bastard Margarelon
Hath Doreus prisoner,
And stands colossus-wise, waving his beam,
Upon the pashed corses of the kings
Epistrophus and Cedius: Polyxenes is slain,
Amphimachus and Thoas deadly hurt,
Patroclus ta'en or slain, and Palamedes
Sore hurt and bruised: the dreadful Sagittary
Appals our numbers: haste we, Diomed,
To reinforcement, or we perish all.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Go, bear Patroclus' body to Achilles;
And bid the snail-paced Ajax arm for shame.
There is a thousand Hectors in the field:
Now here he fights on Galathe his horse,
And there lacks work; anon he's there afoot,
And there they fly or die, like scaled sculls
Before the belching whale; then is he yonder,
And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge,
Fall down before him, like the mower's swath:
Here, there, and every where, he leaves and takes,
Dexterity so obeying appetite
That what he will he does, and does so much
That proof is call'd impossibility.

linegroup.speaker: ULYSSES
linegroup.line: O, courage, courage, princes! great Achilles
Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance:
Patroclus' wounds have roused his drowsy blood,
Together with his mangled Myrmidons,
That noseless, handless, hack'd and chipp'd, come to him,
Crying on Hector. Ajax hath lost a friend
And foams at mouth, and he is arm'd and at it,
Roaring for Troilus, who hath done to-day
Mad and fantastic execution,
Engaging and redeeming of himself
With such a careless force and forceless care
As if that luck, in very spite of cunning,
Bade him win all.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Troilus! thou coward Troilus!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Ay, there, there.

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: So, so, we draw together.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Where is this Hector?
Come, come, thou boy-queller, show thy face;
Know what it is to meet Achilles angry:
Hector? where's Hector? I will none but Hector.

section.title: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Troilus, thou coward Troilus, show thy head!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Troilus, I say! where's Troilus?

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: What wouldst thou?

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: I would correct him.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: Were I the general, thou shouldst have my office
Ere that correction. Troilus, I say! what, Troilus!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: O traitor Diomed! turn thy false face, thou traitor,
And pay thy life thou owest me for my horse!

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: Ha, art thou there?

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: I'll fight with him alone: stand, Diomed.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: He is my prize; I will not look upon.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Come, both you cogging Greeks; have at you both!

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Yea, Troilus? O, well fought, my youngest brother!

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Now do I see thee, ha! have at thee, Hector!

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Pause, if thou wilt.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: I do disdain thy courtesy, proud Trojan:
Be happy that my arms are out of use:
My rest and negligence befriends thee now,
But thou anon shalt hear of me again;
Till when, go seek thy fortune.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Fare thee well:
I would have been much more a fresher man,
Had I expected thee. How now, my brother!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Ajax hath ta'en AEneas: shall it be?
No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven,
He shall not carry him: I'll be ta'en too,
Or bring him off: fate, hear me what I say!
I reck not though I end my life to-day.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Stand, stand, thou Greek; thou art a goodly mark:
No? wilt thou not? I like thy armour well;
I'll frush it and unlock the rivets all,
But I'll be master of it: wilt thou not,
beast, abide?
Why, then fly on, I'll hunt thee for thy hide.

section.title: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Come here about me, you my Myrmidons;
Mark what I say. Attend me where I wheel:
Strike not a stroke, but keep yourselves in breath:
And when I have the bloody Hector found,
Empale him with your weapons round about;
In fellest manner execute your aims.
Follow me, sirs, and my proceedings eye:
It is decreed Hector the great must die.

section.para: Enter MENELAUS and PARIS, fighting: then THERSITES

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: The cuckold and the cuckold-maker are at it. Now,
bull! now, dog! 'Loo, Paris, 'loo! now my double-
henned sparrow! 'loo, Paris, 'loo! The bull has the
game: ware horns, ho!

linegroup.speaker: MARGARELON
linegroup.line: Turn, slave, and fight.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: What art thou?

linegroup.speaker: MARGARELON
linegroup.line: A bastard son of Priam's.

linegroup.speaker: THERSITES
linegroup.line: I am a bastard too; I love bastards: I am a bastard
begot, bastard instructed, bastard in mind, bastard
in valour, in every thing illegitimate. One bear will
not bite another, and wherefore should one bastard?
Take heed, the quarrel's most ominous to us: if the
son of a whore fight for a whore, he tempts judgment:
farewell, bastard.

linegroup.speaker: MARGARELON
linegroup.line: The devil take thee, coward!

section.title: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: Most putrefied core, so fair without,
Thy goodly armour thus hath cost thy life.
Now is my day's work done; I'll take good breath:
Rest, sword; thou hast thy fill of blood and death.

section.para: Puts off his helmet and hangs his shield behind him

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Look, Hector, how the sun begins to set;
How ugly night comes breathing at his heels:
Even with the vail and darking of the sun,
To close the day up, Hector's life is done.

linegroup.speaker: HECTOR
linegroup.line: I am unarm'd; forego this vantage, Greek.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: Strike, fellows, strike; this is the man I seek.
So, Ilion, fall thou next! now, Troy, sink down!
Here lies thy heart, thy sinews, and thy bone.
On, Myrmidons, and cry you all amain,
'Achilles hath the mighty Hector slain.'
Hark! a retire upon our Grecian part.

linegroup.speaker: MYRMIDONS
linegroup.line: The Trojan trumpets sound the like, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: ACHILLES
linegroup.line: The dragon wing of night o'erspreads the earth,
And, stickler-like, the armies separates.
My half-supp'd sword, that frankly would have fed,
Pleased with this dainty bait, thus goes to bed.
Come, tie his body to my horse's tail;
Along the field I will the Trojan trail.

section.title: SCENE IX. Another part of the plains.
section.para: Enter AGAMEMNON, AJAX, MENELAUS, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and others, marching. Shouts within

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: Hark! hark! what shout is that?

linegroup.speaker: NESTOR
linegroup.line: Peace, drums!
Achilles! Achilles! Hector's slain! Achilles.

linegroup.speaker: DIOMEDES
linegroup.line: The bruit is, Hector's slain, and by Achilles.

linegroup.speaker: AJAX
linegroup.line: If it be so, yet bragless let it be;
Great Hector was a man as good as he.

linegroup.speaker: AGAMEMNON
linegroup.line: March patiently along: let one be sent
To pray Achilles see us at our tent.
If in his death the gods have us befriended,
Great Troy is ours, and our sharp wars are ended.

section.title: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: Stand, ho! yet are we masters of the field:
Never go home; here starve we out the night.

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Hector is slain.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: Hector! the gods forbid!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: He's dead; and at the murderer's horse's tail,
In beastly sort, dragg'd through the shameful field.
Frown on, you heavens, effect your rage with speed!
Sit, gods, upon your thrones, and smile at Troy!
I say, at once let your brief plagues be mercy,
And linger not our sure destructions on!

linegroup.speaker: AENEAS
linegroup.line: My lord, you do discomfort all the host!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: You understand me not that tell me so:
I do not speak of flight, of fear, of death,
But dare all imminence that gods and men
Address their dangers in. Hector is gone:
Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba?
Let him that will a screech-owl aye be call'd,
Go in to Troy, and say there, Hector's dead:
There is a word will Priam turn to stone;
Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives,
Cold statues of the youth, and, in a word,
Scare Troy out of itself. But, march away:
Hector is dead; there is no more to say.
Stay yet. You vile abominable tents,
Thus proudly pight upon our Phrygian plains,
Let Titan rise as early as he dare,
I'll through and through you! and, thou great-sized coward,
No space of earth shall sunder our two hates:
I'll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still,
That mouldeth goblins swift as frenzy's thoughts.
Strike a free march to Troy! with comfort go:
Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.

section.para: As TROILUS is going out, enter, from the other side, PANDARUS

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: But hear you, hear you!

linegroup.speaker: TROILUS
linegroup.line: Hence, broker-lackey! ignomy and shame
Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name!

linegroup.speaker: PANDARUS
linegroup.line: A goodly medicine for my aching bones! O world!
world! world! thus is the poor agent despised!
O traitors and bawds, how earnestly are you set
a-work, and how ill requited! why should our
endeavour be so loved and the performance so loathed?
what verse for it? what instance for it? Let me see:
Full merrily the humble-bee doth sing,
Till he hath lost his honey and his sting;
And being once subdued in armed tail,
Sweet honey and sweet notes together fail.
Good traders in the flesh, set this in your
painted cloths.
As many as be here of pander's hall,
Your eyes, half out, weep out at Pandar's fall;
Or if you cannot weep, yet give some groans,
Though not for me, yet for your aching bones.
Brethren and sisters of the hold-door trade,
Some two months hence my will shall here be made:
It should be now, but that my fear is this,
Some galled goose of Winchester would hiss:
Till then I'll sweat and seek about for eases,
And at that time bequeathe you my diseases.
